**Chapter Forty-Five: The Chapter on Great Achievement as Deficiency**

Great **achievement** appears as **deficiency**—
Its use is unexhausted.

Great **fullness** seems **empty**—
Its use is inexhaustible.

Great **straightness** bends,
Great **skill** appears clumsy,
Great **eloquence** stumbles—
**Haste** overcomes **cold**,
**Stillness** overcomes **heat**,
**Purity and stillness** are the **norm** for the world.

The **Classic** says:
Great **achievement** appears as **deficiency**—
Its use is unexhausted.
Great **fullness** seems **empty**—
Its use is inexhaustible.
Thus, great **straightness** bends,
Great **skill** appears clumsy,
Great **eloquence** stumbles—
Meaning **haste** overcomes **cold**,
**Stillness** overcomes **heat**,
**Purity and stillness** are the **norm** for the world.

The **Dao** says:
The **Heavenly Cycle** completes **365¼ degrees** yet does not reach six—
Vigorous yet unceasing;
The **Earth’s** square expanse, a thousand **li**—
Nine yet not ten—
Life-giving yet unexhausted—
Great **achievement** appears as **deficiency**,
Its use is unexhausted.

Heaven’s **sphere**, a hundred eighty thousand **li**,
Earth’s **four quarters**, sixty-four thousand **li**,
The **fixed paths** of sun and moon, fifty-four thousand **li**,
The **Heaven above Earth**, eight thousand four hundred **li**—
Heaven covers without favor,
Earth bears without favor,
Sun and moon shine without favor,
All things ascend to the **Void City**,
Hide in the **Embrace-Bag**—
When exhausted, they transform;
When transformed, they circulate;
When circulating, they endure—
Great **fullness** seems **empty**,
Its use is inexhaustible.

**Qian (Heaven)**—
In stillness, it is **concentrated**,
In motion, it is **straight**—
If **Qian** is not straight, it lacks **angles**.
If **Kun (Earth)** lacks **angles**, it lacks **squares**—
Thus, great **straightness** bends—
Hence, **bending** and **trust** respond, giving rise to **benefit**.
**Kān (Water)**, master of **wisdom**, generates **wood** in **Zhèn (Thunder)**—
Roots, sprouts, flowers, fruit—
None are unclean or disordered—
Water benefits all things yet does not contend—
Thus, great **skill** appears clumsy.

The **Way** unfolds without governance, yet the four seasons march in order,
Great eloquence seems slow of speech—
The **virtuous person** desires to be slow in words yet swift in deeds.

Agitation overcomes cold,
Stillness overcomes heat—
This is the inevitable **principle**.

Thus, the **Sage** ever preserves the **Dao** of **clearing and stillness**,
Taking it as the **rectification** for all under heaven.

**Virtue** speaks:
The body gathers its **great completion**,
Daring not to be full—
Circulating through the **Six Jia**, meeting the **Fighter**,
Upper crescent lacks gold—its use is not exhausted,
Lower crescent lacks silver—its use is not renewed.

**Great surging, great fullness**—
Sun and moon face heaven and earth—**Qian**.
**Unworn, unexhausted**—
Sun and moon meet in heaven and earth—**Kun**.

**Great straightness** bends—
The inchworm’s bending seeks **trust**.
**Great skill** seems clumsy—
Creation nurtures all things, yet clings to **Oneness**.
**Great eloquence** seems slow—
Transcending past and present, daring not to speak.

Agitation overcomes cold—**Fire and Water** yet unfulfilled.
Stillness overcomes heat—**Water and Fire** fulfilled.
**Clearing and stillness** are the **rectification** for all under heaven,
Form and spirit both refined—harmonizing with **True Dao**.

**Chapter 46: The World in Harmony**
When the **Way** prevails, warhorses are turned to plow.
When the **Way** decays, warhorses breed in the suburbs.
No guilt is greater than **desire**,
No calamity greater than **not knowing contentment**,
No blame greater than **grasping what is desired**.

Thus, **knowing contentment** is **constant contentment**.

The **Classic** says:
When the **Way** prevails, warhorses are turned to plow the fields.
When the **Way** decays, warhorses breed in the suburbs.
Seeing what is desirable yet taking it—no guilt is greater.
Seeing sufficiency yet not knowing it—no calamity is greater.
Taking what is desirable—no blame is greater.
Thus, **knowing contentment** is **constant contentment**.

The **Way** says:
**Tang and Wu** revolutionized, conforming to **Heaven** and responding to **humanity**,
When the world was at great peace, horses were returned to the southern slopes of **Hua Mountain**,
Cattle were released into the **Peach Grove** wilds—
Warhorses turned to plow.

In the **Spring and Autumn** era, the **Way** decayed,
Rites, music, and conquests issued from the feudal lords,
The **Four Barbarians** invaded the **Central States**,
Warhorses bred in the suburbs.

The **Five Hegemons** feigned **benevolence** through force—
No guilt greater than **desire**.
A finger in a boat can be grasped—
No calamity greater than **not knowing contentment**.
Borrowing the **Way** from **Yu** to attack **Guo**—
No blame greater than **grasping what is desired**.
Thus it is said: **knowing contentment** is **constant contentment**.

**Virtue** says:
When the **Way** prevails, the body completes its affairs.
**Qian-yang** as horse—vigorous yet unceasing.
True lead, true mercury refined into **pure yang**,
Embrace **Oneness**, guard **Unity**, solidify the foundation—
When the **Way** prevails, warhorses are turned to plow.
Where the master lingers, brambles grow—
After great armies, famine follows—
When the **Way** decays, warhorses breed in the suburbs.

If one sees what is desirable, the mind is disordered—
No guilt is greater.
**Knowing contentment** brings no disgrace,
**Knowing restraint** brings no peril—
Not knowing restraint—no calamity is greater.
**Purple Yang** says:
If not through accumulated **virtue** and cultivated **hidden merit**,
Every action invites **demons** to obstruct.
Seeing the **True Medicine** yet desiring it—
No blame is greater.
Thus it is said: **knowing contentment** is **constant contentment**.

**Chapter 47: Not Leaving the Door**
Not leaving the door, yet knowing all under heaven;
Not peering through the window, yet seeing **Heaven’s Way**.
The farther one goes, the less one knows.
Thus, the **Sage** knows without traveling, names without seeing, accomplishes without doing.

The **Classic** says:
Not leaving the door, yet knowing all under heaven;
Not peering through the window, yet seeing **Heaven’s Way**.
The farther one goes, the less one knows.
Thus, the **Sage** knows without further travel,
Names without needing to see,
Accomplishes without action.

The **Way** says:
The **Sage** exhausts **principle**, fulfills **nature**, reaching even **fate**—
What ears and eyes cannot perceive, by **principle** it is deduced,
Thus, a thousand-year calendar may be achieved while seated.
The more the mind strays, the less it knows.
Mastering **Oneness**, all affairs are complete.
Thus, the **Sage** shuts the **Four Gates**, opens the **Four Eyes**, penetrates the **Four Hearings**,
Taking all under heaven’s **knowing** as **knowing**, yet not acting,
Taking all under heaven’s **name** as **name**, yet not revealing,
Taking all under heaven’s **accomplishment** as **accomplishment**, yet not doing.

**Virtue** says:
Sitting is **establishment**, standing is **extinction**—
How could one leave the door if unaware of all under heaven?
Entering and exiting unobstructed—
How could one peer through the window if unaware of **Heaven’s Way**?
Thus, **virtue’s** perfection is **round** and **spiritual**—
The **spirit** knows no bounds—
The farther it goes, the nearer it returns.
**Knowledge** of **knowledge**—
The less it knows, the more it grasps.
Thus, the **Sage** gazes upward and downward,
Knows without traveling, names without seeing.
Before plows and boats, taking from the **thirteen trigrams’** symbols,
Accomplishes without doing.

**Master Kang** says:
Ears and eyes bright—yet the body remains poor.
The **Great Balance** has not fully bestowed.
Must explore the **Moon’s Cavern** to know things,
Before ascending the **Heavenly Root** to recognize **humanity**.
When **Qian** meets **Xun**, observe the **Moon’s Cavern**,
When **Earth** encounters **Xiao**, see the **Heavenly Root**.
Between the **Heavenly Root** and **Moon’s Cavern**, freely roam—
Thirty-six palaces, all spring.

Again:
The **Heavenly Heart** returns to **Non-heart**,
The **heart** seeks it in vain at all times.
If one says **Non-heart** means **no affairs**,
Why does **gold** arise from **water**?

Again:
Fleeing to **Wu** and **Yue** to seek the **Azure Sky**,
Yet unaware—**Heaven** is before one’s eyes.
**Master Yao**’s **knowing** still did not require leaving the door or peering through the window—
How much more so for the **Sage**?

**Chapter 48: Daily Learning**
Daily learning increases,
Daily **Dao** decreases.
Decrease it again, decrease it again,
Until **non-action**—
**Non-action**, yet nothing remains undone.

Thus, to take the realm,
One must act with **non-action**—
Yet when action arises,
It proves insufficient to take the realm.

The **Classics** say:
*"To learn is to daily increase,
To cultivate the **Dao** is to daily decrease.
Decrease again, decrease again,
Until **non-action**—
**Non-action**, yet nothing remains undone."*

Those who can take the realm
Must act with **non-action**—
Yet when action arises,
It proves insufficient to take the realm.

The **Dao** says:
*"Daily know what you lack,
Monthly forget not what you possess—
This is daily learning.
One day, restrain yourself and return to **ritual**,
And the realm will turn toward **virtue**—
This is daily decreasing in **Dao**."*

Learning and **Dao**, though not separate,
Are yet far apart.
To enter the **Dao**, one must first learn—
Without learning, one knows not the **Dao**,
Hence it is said: *"To learn is to daily increase."*
Yet when one reaches the **Dao**,
Learning is inherently nonexistent—
If one still clings to learning as master,
It will only harm the **Dao**.
One must decrease what is learned
Before entering the **Dao**,
Hence it is said: *"To cultivate the **Dao** is to daily decrease."*

Is it merely daily decreasing?
Decrease again, decrease again,
Until **self** and **all** are exhausted—
Only then does one reach **non-action**.
**Non-action**, yet nothing remains undone.
When the **Dao** of the realm is attained,
What further need is there for action?

Thus, the **Sage** takes all that can be done,
Ever maintaining **non-action** in body and mind,
And finds fulfillment within.
Yet when action arises,
It is seized upon—
And yet it remains insufficient to take the realm.

**Virtue** says:
*"Daily use money and shoes—
This is daily learning.
Mysterious **non-action**—
This is daily decreasing in **Dao**.*
The **Mysterious Law** has three thousand six hundred gates—
Learners cling to one as root—
This is daily learning.
Who knows the slightest **Dao** of the **Immortal**,
Not found in the three thousand six hundred gates—
This is daily decreasing in **Dao**.
Decrease again, decrease again,
Until **non-action**—
**Non-action**, not *not-doing*,
But **non-action** while doing—
Great doing indeed.
Thus, to take the realm, one must act with **non-action**.

To cure before illness arises—
Illness cannot be cured.
When sickness has formed and is treated,
When disease has formed and is attacked—
It is like digging a well when already thirsty.
Is this not too late?
Hence it is said:
When action arises,
It proves insufficient to take the realm.

Taking the hearts of the people as his own.
The good, I also make good;
The ungood, I also make good—
**Virtue** is thus good.
The trustworthy, I also trust;
The untrustworthy, I also trust—
**Virtue** is thus trustworthy.

The **Sage** in the realm,
Ever blending hearts with the people,
While the people fix their ears and eyes,
The **Sage** treats them all as infants.

Thus, the good, I also make good;
The ungood, I also make good—
My **virtue** is good.
The trustworthy, I also trust;
The untrustworthy, I also trust—
My **virtue** is trustworthy.
The **Sage** in the realm,
Long maintaining **incarnate reverence**,

Thus, the **Sage** has no constant heart,
Taking the hearts of the people as his own.
The good, I also make good—

The ungood, I also make good—
What does this mean?
If they are taught and transformed,

Thus it is said: *My **virtue** is good.*
The trustworthy, I also trust—
This is already trustworthy.
The untrustworthy, I also trust—
What does this mean?
If they are taught and transformed,
How do we know they will not become trustworthy?
Thus it is said: *My **virtue** is trustworthy.*

Therefore, the **Sage** in the realm,
Long maintaining **incarnate reverence**,
Ever blending hearts with the people.
**Emperor Yao** was serene and reverent,
Profoundly respectful and yielding,
His radiance extending to all quarters,
His harmony reaching above and below—
Thus the people gazed upon him like the sun and moon,
Regarded him as parents,
All fixing their ears and eyes
To hear of the realm’s governance.
The **Sage** also cherishes them as infants,
Viewing them as if wounded—

**Virtue** says:

The constant heart is **Spirit**.
The people are the **zang-fu** organs.
As the five **zang** organs each have **Spirit**,

As the five **zang** organs each have **essence**,

The **Sage**, having no constant heart,
Takes the hearts of the people as his own—
Thus he attains mastery over **Spirit**,
Hence it is said:

**Spirit** is mysterious and governance unified,
True **qi** harmoniously ascends—

Generate and restrain each other,

Hence it is said:

The unbeneficial **qi**—

The **Sage** in the realm,
**Spirit** and **humanity** in the heart—
Unsettled yet settled,

**Spirit** and **humanity** blend their **qi** with the five **zang**,

Shun ruled the realm,
Selected from the masses,

Selected from the masses,

**Chapter Fifty: Life and Death**

Life and death are but two paths—
Thirteen parts of ten lead to life,
Thirteen parts of ten lead to death,
And thirteen parts of ten bring humanity into perilous grounds of death.

Why is this so?
Because of the **Dao**’s abundant nurturing of life.

It is said that those who skillfully cultivate life
Walk upon land without encountering **rhi** or **tiger**,
Enter battle without being struck by armor or weapons.

The **rhi** finds no place to lodge its horns,
The **tiger** finds no place to set its claws,
The weapons find no place to hold their blades.

Why is this so?
Because there are no grounds of death.

The **Classics** state:
To go forth is to live,
To enter is to die.
Of those who live by the **Dao**’s nurturing, thirteen parts of ten thrive,
Of those who die by their own doing, thirteen parts of ten perish,
And thirteen parts of ten bring humanity into perilous grounds of death.

Why is this so?
Because of the **Dao**’s abundant nurturing of life.

It is said that those who excel in the **Dao** of nurturing life
Walk upon land without encountering **rhi** or **tiger**,
Enter battle without being struck by armor or weapons.

Thus, the **rhi** has no place to lodge its horns,
The **tiger** has no place to set its claws,
The weapons have no place to hold their blades.

Why is this so?
Because the **Dao** contains no grounds of death.

The **Dao** speaks:
Heaven is the realm where thirteen parts of ten thrive,
Earth is the realm where thirteen parts of ten perish,
And humanity, when stirred into motion, also falls into thirteen parts of ten grounds of death.

To go forth is to live,
To enter is to die.
Life is the root of death,
Death is the root of life—
This is the **Dao** of returning to origins and completing the cycle.

Heaven and Earth as one, a single cycle of **129,600 years**.
Heaven has ten **Gān** (heavenly stems), from **Jiǎ** to **Gēng**, seven positions totaling **97,200 years**—Heaven’s life-number.
**Xīn, Rén, and Guǐ**, three positions totaling **38,810 years**—Heaven’s death-number.
Thus, thirteen parts of ten thrive.

Earth has twelve **Zhī** (earthly branches). From the summer solstice, **Yín** to **Xū**, nine positions totaling **97,200 years**—Earth’s life-number.
**Hài, Zǐ, and Chǒu**, three positions totaling **32,400 years**—Earth’s death-number.
Thus, thirteen parts of ten perish.

Twelve multiplied by nine—also seven parts of ten.
Heaven and Earth in one year, **360 days**, from **Kāiwù Yín** to **Bìwù Xū**, **270 days**—Earth’s life-number.
**Hài, Zǐ, Chǒu**, three months, **90 days**—Earth’s death-number.

**Qián** and **Kūn**’s cycles, **360 days** in total—
From **Jiǎ** to **Gēng**, **252 days**—Heaven’s life-number.
**Xīn, Rén, Guǐ**, three positions, **108 days**—Heaven’s death-number.
Thus, it is said: thirteen parts of ten thrive, thirteen parts of ten perish.

**Kāng Jié** said: The exchange of Heaven and Earth, thirteen parts of ten—this is precisely it.
**Kūn**’s number is **108**, now used by the **Buddhist School** in studies of day and night.

Human day and night, **100 kè**, totaling **13,500 breaths**,
Subtracting **4 kè** of decay, leaving **12,960 breaths**.
From **Yín** to **Xū**, **9,720 breaths**—human life-number.
**Hài, Zǐ, Chǒu**, three times, **3,240 breaths**—human death-number.
Thus, it is said: humanity’s motion into grounds of death is also thirteen parts of ten.

**Kāng Jié** said: Heaven does not rest in winter and spring, yet cannot nurture life;
Humanity does not rest in night and day, yet cannot discern affairs.

Modern scholars cultivate for others,
Those who speak do not know.

Heaven speaks not—
The four seasons march in its course;
Earth speaks not—
The myriad things grow in its embrace.
The wise do not speak.

With reverence, they teach the people their proper times;
They follow the **symbols** of sun and moon;
Eastward they till, westward they harvest;
They smooth the **valleys** and divide the **hills**—
Those who speak do not know.

Thus it is said:
When the **Great Dao** is abandoned,
There arise **ren** and **yi**,
And **wisdom** and **cleverness** emerge—
This is the **Great Deception**.

Better to close its **mouth** (兑) and not speak,
For speech not guided by the **Dao** is no speech.
Better to shut its **door** (门) and not act,
For action not guided by the **Dao** is no action.
To dull the **sharpness** of all things and speak,
So that they bear **great fruit**.
To unravel the **chaos** of the people,
So that they follow their **tasks**.
To blend the **light** of sun and moon,
To unify the **dust** of the world—
Though called **mysterious unity of Heaven**, this is **mysterious unity**.

Thus, those who embrace this **Dao**,
Do not serve kings or nobles,
Hold their **affairs** high and pure—
Therefore, they cannot be drawn near,
Cannot be pushed away,
Cannot be used for gain,
Cannot be used for harm,
Cannot be exalted,
Cannot be belittled.

The **Son of Heaven** cannot command them as subjects,
The feudal lords cannot claim them as friends—
Is this not to be held in honor by the world?

**Virtue** is spoken of thus:
Those who perceive **heart** and **nature** to the point of **command**,
Retreat and hide in **secrecy**,
Fearful that others may know—
Would they dare to shape words?

To glimpse a leopard through a tube,
Seeing only a patch—
Yet they strive to boast to others,
Fearful that they may not be known—
Would they dare not to speak?

Thus it is said:
The wise do not speak;
Those who speak do not know.

**Purple Yang** says:
*"Do not comprehend the inverted meaning within,
Do not presume to speak of things seen through a tube."*

Thus, those who have mastered this **Dao**,
Close its **yin mouth** (兑),
Shut its **yang door** (门),
Dull its **empty words**,
Unravel its **clamor**,
Blend its **radiance**,
Unify its **worldly dust**—
This is called **mysterious unity**.

**Mysterious** is called **unity**,
**Unity** is called **mysterious**—
**Mysterious** yet again **mysterious**,
The **gate of all wonders**.

It cannot be drawn near—
No proximity.
It cannot be pushed away—
No distance.
It cannot be used for gain—
No benefit.
It cannot be used for harm—
No loss.
It cannot be exalted—
No reverence.
It cannot be belittled—
No contempt.

Therefore, it is held in honor by the world.

**Chapter Fifty-Seven: Govern with Rectitude**
Govern with **rectitude**,
Employ the **unexpected** in war,
Take the world with **non-action**.

How do I know this to be true?
By this.

The world abounds in taboos,
Yet the people grow ever poorer.

Men multiply sharp tools,
And the state grows ever more confused.

The people multiply clever arts,
And strange things proliferate.

Laws and decrees grow ever more explicit,
Yet thieves and robbers abound.

Therefore, the Sage says:
*"If I act with non-action, the people transform themselves;
If I take no action, the people grow rich;
If I love stillness, the people align themselves;
If I have no desires, the people return to simplicity."*

The Classic states:
*"Govern with rectitude,
Employ the unexpected in war,
Take the world with non-action."*

How do I know this to be true?
By this **Dao**.

When the world abounds in taboos,
Yet the people grow ever poorer;
When men multiply sharp tools,
And the state grows ever more confused;
When the people multiply clever arts,
And strange things proliferate;
When laws and decrees grow ever more explicit,
Yet thieves and robbers abound—
All these are the effects of **action**.

Therefore, the Sage speaks, referring to the Three Sovereigns:
*"If I act with non-action, the people transform themselves;
If I take no action, the people grow rich;
If I love stillness, the people align themselves;
If I have no desires, the people return to simplicity."*

The **Dao** declares:
*"If the state is not governed with rectitude, it cannot be ruled;
If war is not waged with the unexpected, it cannot be won;
If the world is not taken with non-action, it cannot be claimed."*

How do I know this to be true?
By this **Dao**.

The people of the world do not suffer from poverty but from instability,
Nor from scarcity but from inequity.
For when equity is achieved, there is no poverty;
When harmony prevails, there is no scarcity;
When stability is secured, there is no upheaval.
Yet when actions are constrained by taboos,
The people grow ever poorer.

In the age of antiquity,
Rustic cups of mud and earthen drums were deemed proper rites,
Yet still sufficient to appease the spirits and gods—
The rites and music of that time were simple,
And the common folk possessed unfeigned sincerity.

In later ages,
Sacrificial grains and wine were displayed in halls,
Jade and bronze vessels adorned the doors,
With pipes, bells, strings, and bamboo—
Yet the spirits and gods were often unappeased—
For the rites and music had grown elaborate,
And the noble lost their sincerity.
The people multiplied their clever tools,
And the state grew ever more confused.

Meng Tian’s innovations began with non-action,
Yet he turned what was useless into what was useful,
And what was strange into what was practical—
Thus, flying wheels, crooked arrows, wooden oxen, and flowing horses were made,
And the people multiplied their clever arts,
While strange things proliferated.

When a single law reaches its limit,
A hundred deceits arise;
When an edict is issued,
A hundred frauds emerge—
Thus, when laws and decrees grow ever more explicit,
Thieves and robbers abound.

Therefore, the Sage speaks:
*"If I act with non-action, the people transform themselves—*
*Through the Dao transforming the Dao.*
*If I take no action, the people grow rich—*
*Through virtue teaching virtue.*
*If I love stillness, the people align themselves—*
*Through merit encouraging merit.*
*If I have no desires, the people return to simplicity—*
*Through strength commanding strength."*

Within these words lie the **Dao** of the **Huangdi**, the **Wang**, and the **Ba**.
**Virtue** declares:
*"To govern the state with rectitude,
And to guard one’s self with the Dao of rectitude.*
*To wage war with the unexpected,
And to gather medicines with the unexpected.*
*To claim the world with non-action,
And to nurture life without illness."*

Yet when decay sets in and action is taken,
It is no longer sufficient to claim the world.

Thus it is said:
*"How do I know this to be true?
By this **Dao**."*

The **Dao** is not difficult, yet the petty paths are most arduous.
The **Dao** knows no taboos, yet petty paths abound with them.

When the world teems with taboos, the people grow ever poorer;
When petty paths bristle with taboos, the self grows ever more diminished.

When men wield many sharp tools, the state grows ever more benighted;
When the self clings to many side paths, the mind grows ever more disordered.

When the people master many arts, strange things proliferate;
When the self guards with sturdy armor, sharp blades take life.

When laws grow ever more explicit, thieves and robbers multiply;
When precepts grow ever stricter, thieves grow ever more cunning.

All these are the work of petty paths.

Thus the Sage declares:
*"If I take no action, the people transform themselves—*
*By returning to their natural state.*
*If I have no affairs, the people grow rich—*
*By embracing simplicity.*
*If I love stillness, the people align themselves—*
*By reducing selfishness.*
*If I have no desires, the people return to simplicity—*
*By cultivating few desires."*

All these are the work of the **Great Dao**.

Why did the ancients hold this Dao/Way in such esteem? Was it not because it grants what one seeks and pardons transgressions? Therefore, it is the most precious for all under Heaven.

The Classic states:
*The Dao/Way is the essence of all things,
the treasure of the virtuous,
the refuge of the unvirtuous.*
Fine words can be sold at a fair price,
and noble conduct can be bestowed upon others.
What is there to discard in those who are unvirtuous?
Already possessing teachers and noble conduct,
what is there to discard?

Thus, when establishing the Son of Heaven and appointing the Three Ministers, even if one were offered the *gǒngbì* and the finest treasures, or precedence in a four-horse chariot, it would not compare to sitting and receiving this Dao/Way. Indeed, this Dao/Way is more precious than the *gǒngbì* and surpasses even the four-horse chariot.

Why did the ancients hold this Dao/Way in such esteem? Do not suppose it is merely a means to gain what one seeks or to avoid punishment—therefore, it is the most precious for all under Heaven.

The *De* (德) declares:
*The Dao/Way is the essence of all things,
the most profound mystery of the world.*
Formless yet manifest, without substance yet bearing likeness,
it arises from the Supreme Polarity’s luminous void.
Before Heaven’s breath coalesces into a single grain,
great as millet—named *jīnjīng* (金晶, Golden Crystal),
also called *zhēnqiān* (真铅, True Lead),
*yángdān* (阳丹, Solar Elixir),
or *Tiānyī* (天一, Heaven-One)—
the treasure of the virtuous.
Though it is the treasure of the virtuous,
it is also the refuge of the unvirtuous.
If one encounters a Sage of the highest order,
what heights cannot be attained?

**Chapter 63: *For Non-Action***

To act in *non-action*,
to govern in *non-governance*,
to savor in *non-savor*—
great or small, much or little,
repay enmity with *virtue/power*.

Plan for difficulty when it is still easy,
achieve the great by beginning with the small.
The world’s difficult tasks must begin in ease,
the world’s great deeds must arise from the minute.
Thus, the Sage never acts in grandeur,
and so achieves true grandeur.

He who lightly promises will seldom keep faith,
he who takes many things lightly will meet many difficulties.
Therefore, the Sage still regards them as difficult,
and so remains without difficulty.

The *Classical Text* declares:
To act in *non-action*,
to govern in *non-governance*,
to savor in *non-savor*.
To attain the great from the small,
to accumulate much from little—
all stem from repaying enmity with *virtue/power*.
Thus, plan for difficulty when it is still easy,
achieve the great by beginning with the small.
For the world’s difficult tasks must begin in ease,
the world’s great deeds must arise from the minute.
Thus, the Sage achieves grandeur by beginning with the small,
never acting in grandeur itself,
and so achieves true grandeur.
Because he regards difficulty as difficulty,
he remains without difficulty.

What does this mean?
He who lightly promises will seldom keep faith,
he who takes many things lightly will meet many difficulties.

The *De* (德) states:
*Non-action* as the foundation of action,
calm conquers agitation.
*Non-governance* as the foundation of governance,
emptiness conquers fullness.
*Non-savor* as the foundation of savor,
simplicity conquers brilliance.

In cultivating the self and nurturing life,
the first essential is a firm and subtle foundation.
A firm and subtle foundation must begin with refining the elixir.
The proverb says:
*"Wealth comes from careful saving,
poverty from failing to compete."*
Do not dismiss good deeds as too small to perform,
nor indulge in evil as too trivial to avoid.
Drips of water, unceasing, become rivers.
The high rests upon the low as its base,
the noble upon the humble as its root—
thus, one repays enmity with *virtue/power*.

Therefore, plan for difficulty when it is still easy,
achieve the great by beginning with the small.
For the world’s difficult tasks must begin in ease,
the world’s great deeds must arise from the minute.
Thus, the Sage fears not attaining grandeur,
never acting in grandeur itself,
and so achieves true grandeur;
fears not facing difficulty,
still regarding it as difficult,
and so remains without difficulty.
To speak of grandeur before attaining it is to lightly promise—
seldom will faith be kept.
To speak of difficulty before overcoming it is to take things lightly—
many difficulties will arise.

**Chapter 64: *Its Ease in Holding***

Its ease lies in being held firm,
its unseen signs are best planned early,
its fragility makes it easy to shatter,
its subtlety disperses with neglect—
act before it manifests,
govern before disorder arises.

A tree thick enough to embrace grows from a slender sprout;
a nine-tiered tower begins with a single clod of earth;
a thousand-li journey starts beneath one’s feet.
To act when it already exists is to court failure,
to grasp when already disordered is to ensure loss.
Thus, the Sage acts in *non-action* and knows no failure,
holds nothing and knows no loss.
Men, in their undertakings, often ruin what is nearly complete.
To finish with the same care as the beginning,
then no task will fail.

Therefore, the Sage desires what others do not,
values not the hard-to-obtain treasures;
learns what others do not learn,
undoes the errors of the multitude,
ever aiding the natural course of all things,
daring not to act.

The *Classical Text* declares:
Its ease lies in being held firm,
its unseen signs are best planned early,
its fragility makes it easy to shatter,
its subtlety disperses with neglect—
thus, act before it manifests,
govern before disorder arises.
For a tree thick enough to embrace grows from a slender sprout;
a nine-tiered tower begins with a single clod of earth;
a thousand-li journey starts beneath one’s feet.
To act when it already exists is to court failure,
to grasp disorder and attempt governance is to ensure loss.
The Sage acts in *non-action* and knows no failure,
holds nothing and knows no loss.
Men, in their undertakings, often falter in their resolve,
and so complete what they ruin.
To finish with the same care as the beginning,
then no task will fail.

Therefore, the Sage desires what others do not desire,
so he does not value hard-to-obtain treasures;
learns what others do not learn,
undoes the errors of the multitude,
ever aiding the natural course of all things,
daring not to act.

The *Dao* declares:
That which is stable is easy to hold,
that which is yet unmanifest is best planned early,
that which is fragile is easy to break,
that which is subtle is easy to disperse—
all must be acted upon before they exist,
governed before they become disordered.

That which is not yet perilous is the Sage who rests secure in his station.
That which is not yet lost is the Sage who preserves what remains.
That which is not yet disordered is the Sage who governs its emergence.

Thus, the virtuous man remains secure yet never forgets danger,
preserves existence yet never forgets loss,
governs yet never forgets chaos—
so his person is secure while his state may be preserved.

The *Classic of Changes* declares:
*"Its loss, its loss—
bound to the mulberry and hemp."*

Thus, the tree that spans a man’s embrace begins as a tiny sprout;
the nine-tiered tower rises from a single clod of earth;
the thousand-li journey commences beneath one’s feet—
these are the inevitable *Dao* of things.

One cannot leap over stages to accomplish them,
nor build upon empty foundations to grasp them—
to act thus is to court ruin,
to hold thus is to invite loss.

The Sage acts in *non-action*, yet progress is truly made,
so he knows no failure.
The Sage does not grasp, yet each step is truly taken,
so he knows no loss.

But men’s undertakings differ from this:
they do not labor for true advancement,
yet often falter in their resolve;
they do not walk the path with genuine steps,
yet often stumble in their deeds—
though they begin, they ruin what they complete.
For completion lies in resolve, yet ruin comes in action;
action, when true, knows no ruin.

Therefore, to finish with the same care as the beginning,
to walk with steady feet upon the earth,
then no task will fail.

All men desire hard-to-obtain treasures,
yet the Sage desires not what they desire—
so he does not value their treasures.

All men learn what others have already erred in,
yet the Sage does not learn what they learn—
so he can undo their mistakes,
aiding the natural course of all things
yet daring not to act presumptuously in affairs.

The *virtue* declares:
Man’s primordial *qi*, each has one *jin*.
At birth, one *jin* of *qi* is but one *dan* in weight.
In one year, the twenty-four *qi* produce one *liang*,
and by sixteen years, one *jin* is fully formed.
After three years past this, one *liang* is consumed,
and by sixty-four years, one *jin* is utterly exhausted.
Thus, the eighty-eight *guà* of a man’s life span,
his primordial *qi* is spent.

When primordial *qi* is stable and secure,
it is very easy to hold firm against peril;
when primordial *qi* is faint and unclear,
it is very easy to plan its early signs;
when primordial *qi* is soft and fragile,
it is very easy to shatter its hardness;
when primordial *qi* is subtle and refined,
it is very easy to disperse its lodging.

To act before things arise,
then there is no need for action;
to govern before things become disordered,
then there is no need for governance.

The tree that spans a man’s embrace begins as a tiny sprout—
this is the *yang* spirit’s interaction with the *qi*.
The nine-tiered tower rises from a single clod of earth—
this is the *golden elixir*’s refinement in the *jing*.
The thousand-li journey commences beneath one’s feet—
this is the *valley spirit*’s reliance on the *dark mother*.

Each step must be firmly trodden,
no shortcuts allowed.
To act by shortcuts is to court ruin,
to grasp by artifice is to invite loss.

The Sage acts in *non-action* yet does nothing without effect,
so he knows no failure.
He does not grasp yet does nothing without holding,
so he knows no loss.

But men’s ways in these matters are otherwise:
they do not know the great *Dao* of *non-action*,
spitting out the old and taking in the new,
seeking solitude and stillness,
long in the use of resolve yet short in the use of action—
sometimes open, sometimes blocked,
half secure, half perilous,
with occasional small successes,
yet ruined at the turn of a hand.
How could they exhaust the principles and reach the essence,
thus attaining the *Way* of life?

Only by grasping the primordial *non-action* of the *Dao*,
remaining steadfast from beginning to end,
then no task will fail.

The Sage does not desire what men desire—
so he does not value hard-to-obtain treasures;
he does not learn what men learn—
so he can undo the multitude’s errors,
aiding the natural course of all things
yet daring not to act presumptuously.

The *Classic* of the ancient Sage who practiced the *Dao* (Chapter Sixty-Five):
The ancient Sage who practiced the *Dao*
did not seek to enlighten the people,
but rather to keep them in simplicity.
The people are hard to govern,
because their cleverness is too great.

Thus, to govern the state with cleverness is to be its thief;
to govern the state without cleverness is to be its blessing.
These two are the people’s models.

To always know these models,
this is called *mysterious virtue*.
The *mysterious virtue* is profound and distant,
contrary to the ways of things—
then only does it reach the great harmony.

The text declares:
The ancient Sage who practiced the *Dao*
did not seek to make the people use its wisdom,
but rather to make them use its simplicity.
The people are hard to govern,
because their cleverness is too great.
Thus, to govern the state with cleverness is to be its thief;
to govern the state without cleverness is to be its blessing.
These two are the people’s models.

To always know these models,
this is called *mysterious virtue*.
The *mysterious virtue* is profound and distant,
contrary to the ways of things—
then only does it reach the great harmony.

The *Dao* declares:
The people can be made to follow,
but cannot be made to understand.
There are those who govern others,
and those who are governed by others—
thus the people can be led to joyful success,
but cannot be made to share in planning its beginnings.

If the people are made to understand,
it is like commanding them to build a house on the highway—
three years, yet it will never be finished.
Thus, the ancient Sage who practiced the *Dao*
did not seek to make the people use the *Dao*’s wisdom,
but rather to make them use the *Dao*’s simplicity.

To use the *Dao*’s wisdom is the way of the Sage—
without the virtuous, none can govern the common folk.
To use the *Dao*’s simplicity is the way of the common folk—
without the common folk, none can nurture the Sage.

If the people use the *Dao*’s wisdom,
they will vie for cleverness and craftiness,
their hearts laboring while their days grow ever more incompetent.
If the people use the *Dao*’s simplicity,
they will return to purity and revert to simplicity,
their hearts at ease while their days grow ever more restful.

When the common folk use the *Dao* yet do not know it,
the *Dao* of the virtuous is still rare—
how much more so the *Dao* of the Sage?

This is *non-action* yet nothing is left undone.
The foolish, in the *Dao*’s simplicity;
the wise, in the *Dao*’s wisdom—
not to deliberately make the people wise or foolish,
but rather to make them use wisdom and simplicity,
this is the Sage’s artful balance.

The people are hard to govern,
because their cleverness is too great—
to use the *Dao*’s wisdom is to govern with cleverness,
thus to be the state’s thief.
The people are easy to govern,
not because they are simple—
to use the *Dao*’s simplicity is to govern without cleverness,
thus to be the state’s blessing.

To always know these models,
this is called *mysterious virtue*—
the people’s standard of excellence.
To always adhere to these models,
this is called *mysterious virtue*.

The **mysterious virtue** of Heaven is profound and distant,
thus it turns contrary to all things.
Hence it is easily inverted by calculation—
Heaven’s body revolves westward,
while the sun, moon, and five stars move eastward.

Heaven is high in the southeast,
the Earth is high in the northwest,
the Earth is low in the southeast,
Heaven’s *qi* descends,
Earth’s *qi* ascends—
all contrary to things.

When its work is complete,
then it is unified—
thus the *Dao* of Heaven, Earth, and the Sage
does not oppose all ten thousand things,
or else they could not succeed in the world.
Hence it is said: **Only then does it reach the Great Harmony.**

**Virtue** is spoken of:
The *Dao* is the primordial Way of Heaven.
The *Dao* is the sovereign of the human heart,
the divine master of true *qi*.
The people are the five *zàng* organs, six *fǔ* viscera, and twelve *guī* palaces.

The ancients who excelled in cultivating life and nurturing the essence
did not treat the twelve *guī* palaces as clever,
nor did they treat them as simple—
but rather, they made the heart and spirit their master.

If each palace were allowed to govern its own affairs,
then the body would first fall ill—
how could one then nurture the essence?

Thus the people are hard to govern,
because their cleverness is too great—
too much cleverness means they must be governed by cleverness,
not by the Way of non-action.
Hence to govern with cleverness is the state’s thief,
while to govern without cleverness is the state’s blessing.

To know these two models of governing the body and the people,
this is the standard of excellence for life and essence.
To always know the *Dao* of these models,
this is called **mysterious virtue**.

**Mysterious virtue** is profound and distant—
the *Dao* of Heaven, Earth, humanity, and all things’ creation.
All contrary to things,
yet it reaches the Great Harmony without confusion.

The rivers and seas are the sovereigns of all valleys—
Chapter Sixty-Six
The reason the rivers and seas can be sovereigns of all valleys
is that they excel in descending—
thus they can be sovereigns of all valleys.

Therefore, the Sage who wishes to rule above others
speaks with humility below;
who wishes to lead others
places himself behind them.

The Sage thus stands above yet people do not feel burdened,
leads yet people do not feel oppressed—
therefore the world gladly follows and never tires.

Because he does not contend,
none under Heaven can contend with him.

The *Classics* say:
*"The rivers and seas can be sovereigns of all valleys
because they excel in descending—
thus they can be sovereigns of all valleys."*

Therefore, the Sage who seeks to rise above others
must speak with humility below;
who seeks to lead others
must place himself behind them.

Thus the Sage stands above yet people do not deem him heavy,
leads yet people do not deem him harmful—
therefore the world gladly follows and never tires.
Because he does not contend,
none under Heaven can contend with him.

The *Dao* states:
*"Great states are like the lower reaches of rivers—
the rivers and seas can be sovereigns of all valleys
because they excel in descending—
thus they can be sovereigns of all valleys,
mirroring the Earth’s yielding nature (坤之象).*

Though the seas may number four,
the eastern and southern are the largest,
for their nature is to descend.
Thus the tides’ reliability,
even as they travel west beyond a thousand *li* to reach Luoyang,
nearly reaching the center of the Earth.
The reason the island peoples of the eastern and southern seas suffer most from flooding
is that they are near the rivers’ lower reaches—
so it is known that the rivers and seas can be sovereigns of all valleys
only because they descend in their earthly form.

The Sage thus can be above all the myriad people
only because he descends through his words;
his body can lead all the myriad people
only because he places himself behind them."

Thus, by honoring what is low and disregarding what is high, one gains the people’s allegiance.
By speaking before the people, they forget their toil;
by leading them into danger, they forget their fear of death.
By placing themselves behind, they come first;
by abandoning themselves, they are preserved.

Therefore, the Sage stands above the myriad people,
yet they are revered without burden;
he moves before the myriad people,
yet they follow without resistance.

Thus, the world willingly promotes him without tiring,
for he does not contend with the people.

Only he who does not contend
can ensure none contend with him.

**Virtue/Power says:**
The *dantian* and *qihai* are where the *gushen* true-qi converges.
Because they excel in descending,
they receive the homage of all rivers and streams,
able to be sovereigns of the valleys,
nourishing the roots of Heaven and Earth.

Thus, the heart-spirit, adorned above the Five Phases,
must descend through true-qi;
to surpass the Five Phases’ order,
one must yield to blood-qi.

Therefore, the heart-sovereign, named above the Five Phases,
is revered without burden;
the spirit, placed before the Five Phases,
is followed without resistance.

Thus, the four limbs, six pulses, myriad transformations, and hundred bones
willingly promote it without tiring,
for the heart-spirit acts without striving
and does not contend with the Five Phases for precedence.

If there is contention,
then bitterness and suffering do not cease,
acrid and pungent do not harmonize,
serene and bland do not communicate,
emptiness and nothingness do not intermingle,
true-qi does not follow,
spirit does not abide,
and diseases arise—
how can this be called the Way?

Only when the heart-sovereign does not contend
can the Five Phases not contend with it.
Great indeed are these words!

The world says my Way is great, yet seems unworthy.
Only because it is great does it seem unworthy.
If it seemed worthy for long, it would be trifling indeed.

I possess three treasures; I hold them dear.
First: compassion,
Second: frugality,
Third: not daring to act first under Heaven.

Compassion makes one courageous;
frugality makes one expansive;
not daring to act first under Heaven makes one the vessel’s leader.

Now, abandoning compassion and courage,
abandoning frugality and expansiveness,
abandoning humility and precedence—
this is death.

Compassion, when used in war, brings victory;
when used in defense, brings security.
If Heaven intends to save this person,
it will first shield them with compassion,
restrain them with frugality,
and weaken them by not daring to act first under Heaven—
only then can they become the leader of the sacred vessel.

**Virtue/Power says:**
The world says I have attained the great Way,
yet seem unworthy of it.
Because the Way is great, it seems unworthy.
If greatness seemed worthy for long,
it would be the speech of the vulgar, not the enlightened.

The Way fills all under Heaven, permeating all things—
how can there be worthy or unworthy in greatness?

Zhongyong says:
*"Each person has the elixir of longevity,
yet fools discard it in their confusion."*
And again:
*"This supreme treasure is in every home,
yet fools fail to recognize it fully."*

Is it only that the great is the Way?
Thus it is said: I have three treasures; people should cherish and hold them.
First: compassion—no cruelty,
compassion without cruelty makes one courageous.
Second: frugality—no greed,
frugality without greed makes one expansive.
Third: not daring to act first under Heaven—no aggression,
preceding without aggression makes one the vessel’s leader.

Not daring to be the world’s courageous one,
thus one fulfills compassion’s leadership;
not daring to be the world’s expansive one,
thus one fulfills frugality’s leadership;
not daring to act first under Heaven,
thus one fulfills the vessel’s leadership.

Fine weapons are inauspicious instruments;
used only when unavoidable, serenity is supreme.
To win in battle and rejoice is to delight in killing.
Those who delight in killing must be killed—
thus they cannot achieve their desires under Heaven.

Now, abandoning compassion and courage,
and instead indulging in cruelty—

Abandoning frugality yet seeking expansion,
and instead indulging in greed—
abandoning humility yet acting first,
and instead indulging in aggression—
their swift death is certain.

This is the ignorance of compassion,
the foundation of defense and war.
To wage war with compassion,
the world submits to you;
to wage war with cruelty,
your kin betray you.
With what the world submits to,
attack what your kin betray—
thus the virtuous warrior
has no need to fight,
yet when he fights, he is certain to win.

To defend the realm with compassion,
the world aids you;
to defend the realm with greed,
the world despises you.
With what the world aids you in,
defend against what the world despises—
thus the virtuous warrior
has no need to defend,
yet when he defends, he is unshakable.

Therefore, when Heaven intends to bestow the Great Dao
to save this person,
it must make him wield compassion
as his unbreakable armor and sharpest weapon.

**Chapter 68: The Virtuous Warrior**

The virtuous warrior is not aggressive,
the skilled fighter does not rage,
the master of victory does not engage,
the adept at using men places himself below them.

This is called the virtue of non-contention,
this is called the power of using men,
this is called aligning with Heaven’s ancient extremes.

The Classic says:
The virtuous warrior is not aggressive,
the skilled fighter does not rage,
the master of victory does not engage in battle,
the adept at using men first places himself below them.

This is called the virtue of non-contention,
this is called the power of using men,
this is called aligning with Heaven’s ancient extremes.

The Way says:
King Wu crossed the孟津 river,
and the lords of the eight hundred states gathered without summons.
King Wu said: *"It is not yet time."*

After two years, he extinguished Zhou,
and this is called the virtuous warrior not being aggressive.

At the hour of甲子, dawn breaking,
the king arrived at the outskirts of Shang,
and there he swore his oath.
The king held the yellow axe in his left hand,
grasped the white banner in his right,
and waved them—
this is called the skilled fighter not raging.

The enemy’s troops were arrayed like forests,
yet none dared oppose our army.
The vanguard turned their spears and struck from behind,
driving them north.
Blood flowed, staining the battle-axes red,
and the world was at peace—
this is called the master of victory not engaging.

The enemy had countless millions,
their hearts and virtues divided,
while we had but three thousand warriors,
our hearts and virtues united.
Even great states feared our strength,
small states cherished our virtue—
this is called the adept at using men placing himself below them.

Thus King Wu—
this is called the virtue of non-contention,
this is called the power of using men,
this is called aligning with Heaven to set the ancient extremes.

The Virtue says:
The world’s exchange,
the world’s female—
ever with stillness overcoming the male,
ever with stillness placing itself below.

Thus, when yin is above,
yang flees beneath,
the head and tail are aggressive,
the center is refined.
This is knowing that the adept at refining fire
is not solely for aggression—
thus the adept at the Great Dao
is not aggressive yet is aggressive,
not refined yet is refined—
hence, the virtuous warrior is not aggressive.

Strong arms and battlefield victories are still inauspicious—
how much more so when raging in battle?
Thus the skilled fighter does not rage,
subduing the enemy without striking.

The sage’s gaze meets the Dao’s presence,
spirit encountering spirit—
even when tortoises gaze at each other,
cranes call to cranes,
they still meet spirit with spirit—
how much more so for the master of victory?
Thus he does not engage in battle.
The adept at using men places himself below.

The world’s ultimate softness
gallops across the world’s ultimate firmness—
this is called the virtue of non-contention.
Because he does not contend,
none under Heaven can contend with him—
this is called the power of using men.
Give the people what they desire,
remove what they hate—
those who walk this Way
are called aligning with Heaven since ancient times without parallel.

**Chapter 69: The Art of War’s Speeches**

The art of war has this saying:
*"I dare not be the aggressor but only the defender,
I dare not advance an inch but retreat a foot."*

This is called moving without moving,
pushing without arms,
advancing without resistance,
seizing without weapons.

No greater calamity than underestimating the enemy—
underestimating the enemy risks losing our treasure.
Thus when armies clash,
the compassionate one wins.

The Classic says:
The art of war has this saying:
*"I dare not be the aggressor but am always the defender,
I dare not advance an inch but always retreat a foot."*

This is called moving as if not moving,
pushing as if without arms,
advancing as if without resistance,
seizing as if without weapons.
No greater calamity than underestimating the enemy—
underestimating the enemy risks losing our treasure—
thus when armies clash,
the first to show compassion wins.

The Way says:
The military has this saying:
*"Do not dare to be the aggressor—
the army marches by discipline,
losing discipline brings disaster—
yet always be the defender—
this is called the power of using men,
thus one does not dare to be the aggressor but is always the defender."*

Three parts of Shang’s realm
were already held by King Wen,
yet he still served Shang.
For nine years, his great merit was not yet fulfilled,
until King Wu and the Duke of Zhou succeeded him—
this is called not daring to advance an inch but always retreating a foot.

The revolution of Tang and Wu
followed Heaven’s will and responded to the people.
The east was pacified, the west lamented.
*"Our lord has gone—
may those who come after him revive him!"*
The people he left behind
rejoiced in their homes—
this is called moving without moving,
pushing without arms,
advancing without resistance,
seizing without weapons.

The Minor Teacher said:
*"Not opposing the king is not an enemy."*
When Chu defeated him,
this is why he was annihilated at 随.

No greater calamity than underestimating the enemy—
underestimating the enemy risks losing our treasure.
When Wu and Yue clashed in battle,
Yue, unable to resist, begged for submission,
and Wu released them—
later, they were destroyed by Goujian.
Thus it is said:
when armies clash,
the compassionate one wins.

The Virtue says:
Purple Yang says:
*"A pound of medicine requires sixteen ounces,
adjusting the fire’s timing with yin and yang."*

Nurturing medicine requires fire’s timing,
and timing must be balanced between yin and yang.
Fire’s timing has refinement and aggression,
has guest and host—

*Lǐ* originates from *Lián*’s body,
taking the central *yīn* line of *Kūn*—

thus, it is the "central male."
*Lǐ* is externally yang and internally yin—
thus, it is the "central female."

the symbol of *Lǐ*’s fire.
The female is externally yin and internally yang—
the symbol of *Kǎn*’s water.

Human life begins in softness—
the *yīn* within *Lǐ*.
At death, the heart grows rigid—
the single *yáng* within *Kǎn*.
*Yīn* governs death—how then does it speak of life?
*Yáng* governs life—how then does it speak of death?

it would not be called the *Dao*.

Indeed, *yīn* without *yáng* cannot generate,
*yáng* without *yīn* cannot perish—
this is to rob Heaven and Earth of their transformations.
Thus, inversion is necessary—
even for all things, plants, and grasses.

Therefore, the strong descend while the weak ascend,
*yīn* above, *yáng* rushing beneath—

**Chapter Seventy-Seventh: The Way of Heaven**
The *Dao* of Heaven—is it not like drawing a bow?
The high are pressed down, the low are raised,
the excessive are diminished, the deficient are supplemented.
The *Dao* of Heaven diminishes the excessive and supplements the deficient,
but the *Dao* of humanity is otherwise:
it diminishes the deficient to serve the excessive.
Who can use the excessive to nourish the world?
Only the *Dao*-bearer.

Thus, the Sage acts without claiming,
achieves without dwelling—
not desiring to be seen as virtuous.
The *Classic* says:
*The *Dao* of Heaven—is it not like drawing a bow?
The high must be pressed down, the low must be raised,
the excessive must be diminished, the deficient must be supplemented.
The *Dao* of Heaven diminishes the excessive and supplements the deficient,
but the *Dao* of humanity is otherwise:
it diminishes the deficient to serve the excessive.
Who diminishes the excessive to nourish the world?
Only the *Dao*-bearer can do so.

Thus, the Sage acts in *wuwei* yet does not rely on it,
achieves without taking credit—
not desiring to display virtue or praise.
The *Dao* says:
*The *Dao* of Heaven is round and divine,
embracing the great earth,
giving birth and completing all things—
the image of a drawn bow.
The Heaven above the earth
always uses half its arc—
the image of a released bow.
The high are pressed down, the low are raised—
this is the sun yielding to the moon,
the moon yielding to the sun,
day and moon pushing against each other, generating brightness.
Cold yielding to heat, heat yielding to cold,
cold and heat pushing against each other, completing the year.

The excessive are diminished—
autumn harvest, winter storage.
The deficient are supplemented—
spring growth, summer flourishing.
This is called the *Dao* of Heaven:
diminishing the excessive and supplementing the deficient,
gathering the abundant and aiding the scarce,
balancing things and applying evenly.

But the *Dao* of humanity is otherwise:
the deficient are diminished—
the people’s hunger.
The excessive are served—
the ruler’s heavy taxes.
This is called the *Dao* of humanity:
diminishing the deficient to serve the excessive,
plundering the low to raise the high,
severing the short to lengthen the long.

Having diminished the deficient to serve the excessive,
who can then use the excessive to nourish the world’s deficiencies?
Only the *Dao*-bearer can do so.
Thus, the Sage acts in *wuwei* yet does not serve himself,
achieves without taking residence—
not desiring to display virtue or praise,
yet causing the Great *Dao* to lean toward nourishment,
preventing excess and deficiency.

**Chapter Seventy-Eighth: The World’s Gentleness**
Nowhere is the world’s gentleness and weakness greater than in water,
yet nothing can surpass it in overcoming hardness.
Caution—do not treat it lightly.
The weak overcoming the strong, the gentle overcoming the firm—
all know this, yet none can practice it.

Thus, the Sage says:
*"To bear a nation’s filth is to be its sovereign;
to bear a nation’s misfortune is to be its king."*
Straight speech inverted.

The *Classic* says:
*"Nowhere is the world’s gentleness and weakness greater than in water,
yet nothing can surpass it in overcoming hardness—
caution, do not treat it lightly.
The weak overcoming the strong, the gentle overcoming the firm—
all know this, yet none can practice it.
Thus, the Sage says:
To bear a nation’s filth is to be its sovereign;
to bear a nation’s misfortune is to be its king.
To bear filth and rule, to bear misfortune and reign—
the Sage’s straight speech is inverted."*

The *Dao* says:
*Kǎn* is extreme gentleness—
its water ascends and descends between Heaven and Earth.
*Kūn* is slight gentleness—
its earth gives birth and completes all things.
Yet the earth of *Kūn* shapes all things,
while the water of *Kǎn* circulates their *qi*.
Thus, what moistens all things is nothing like water—
hence, the world’s gentleness and weakness are nowhere greater than in water.
Its water and *qi* flow without entering,
yet flow without failing to conquer—
while overcoming hardness, nothing can surpass it.
Caution—do not treat its water lightly.
Water, water—
thus it is said: *It cannot be replaced.*

The *Dao* of weakness overcoming strength, of gentleness conquering rigidity—
the world knows this well, yet none can practice it.
How then could one treat its water as trifling?

Great indeed is the *Dao* of water’s timely virtue.

Thus the Sage declares:
To bear a nation’s filth and humiliation—
this is called the sovereign of the *altars of soil and grain* (社稷).
To bear a nation’s calamities—
this is called the king of the world.
Water embodies this *symbol* (象).

Weakness overcoming strength, gentleness conquering rigidity,
bearing filth to rule, enduring calamity to reign—
all are *straight speech inverted* (正言若反).

The *virtue/power* (德) says:
True *essence* (精) is most gentle,
true *qi* most feeble—
*Kǎn*’s water conceals them,
all bearing names yet no form,
the sovereign of the body.

Once the *essence* and *qi* are exhausted,
though bones and sinews claim firmness,
soon they become dung and dust.

By this reasoning,
the world’s gentleness and feebleness
nowhere surpass water’s,
yet none can conquer hardness as it does.
Who dares to belittle and despise it?

Thus it is said: *It cannot be replaced.*
The *Dao* of water’s gentleness overcoming strength,
of gentleness conquering rigidity—
the world knows this truth,
yet none can enact its practice.
Great indeed is water’s *Dao* as the *Way*.

Thus the Sage declares:
To bear a nation’s filth and humiliation—
this is weakness overcoming strength,
weakness overcoming strength—
this is called the sovereign of the *altars of soil and grain*.
To bear a nation’s calamities—
this is gentleness conquering rigidity,
gentleness conquering rigidity—
this is called the king of the world.
All are *straight speech inverted*.
(*Chapter Seventy-Nine: Harmonizing Great Grievances*)

To reconcile great grievances, there must remain lingering resentment—
how then can it be called good?

Thus the Sage holds the left contract,
yet does not demand recompense from others.

Therefore, those of *virtue* oversee the contract,
while those without oversee the law.

The *Dao* of Heaven favors none,
always aligning with those of goodness.

The *sutra* says:
To reconcile great grievances, there must remain lingering resentment—
how then can it be called good?

Auspicious matters favor the left,
contracts replacing cords and bonds.
Thus the Sage always holds the auspicious covenant,
yet does not demand recompense from others.

Therefore, those of *virtue* oversee the contract,
while those without oversee the law.

*Simpai* (彻) is the law.

The *Dao* of Heaven favors none,
always aligning with those of goodness.

The *Way* declares:
Goodly closures require no bolt or bar yet cannot be opened,
goodly bindings require no cord or knot yet cannot be undone.
When great enmity has already formed and is then resolved,
there must remain lingering enmity—
how then can it be called trustworthy?
When great resentment has already manifested and is then reconciled,
there must remain lingering resentment—
how then can it be called good?

Thus the Sage holds the left contract,
saying: goodly bindings require no cord or knot yet cannot be undone,
and does not demand from others—
this is called goodly closures requiring no bolt or bar yet cannot be opened.
Only those of *virtue* can oversee the contract,
while those without *virtue* merely oversee the law.

Thus the Imperial Heaven favors none,
only *virtue* does it assist;
the *Dao* of Heaven favors none,
always aligning with those of goodness.

*Virtue* says:
When Heaven and Earth unite, sweet dew descends,
when Yin and Yang harmonize, winds and rains come in season—
the beginning of *yīn-yáng*’s *sūn-yǐ* (损益) and flourishing decline.

When three Yangs emerge from Earth, it is *Tāi* (泰) of Earth-Heaven,
Earth-Heaven *Tāi* in square form—
three above intersecting, diminishing its flourishing.
When three Yins emerge from Earth, it is *Pǐ* (否) of Heaven-Earth,
Heaven-Earth *Pǐ* in square form—
the first four intersecting, augmenting its decline.

Thus it is said: the beginning of *sūn-yǐ* and flourishing decline.

Thus *Tāi* can generate things,
I can complete things,
so that all things under Heaven constantly lament
that Heaven and Earth do not practice *sūn-yǐ*.

Great as Heaven and Earth, small as all things,
all rely on *yīn-yáng* to form their vessels—
how much more so for humanity?

When Yang leads and Yin harmonizes,
this is called man and wife dwelling together.
When Yang leads and Yin defies,
this is called husband and wife turning against each other—
how much more so for great grievances?

When great grievance has already formed,
then to reconcile it—
to reconcile and provoke resentment,
there must remain lingering resentment.
With lingering resentment,
how then can it be called good?

When great resentment has already manifested,
then to save it—
to save and provoke anger,
there must remain lingering anger.
With lingering anger,
how then can it be called aid?

Thus the Sage always holds the left contract,
to overcome strength with weakness,
not demanding from others,
to overcome rigidity with gentleness.

Those of *virtue* oversee the contract, holding to gentleness.
Those without *virtue* oversee the law, holding to rigidity.

Thus the *Dao* of Heaven does not falter,
always aligning with the left contract;
the *Dao* of Heaven favors none,
always aligning with those of goodness.

---
*Chapter Eighty: Small States, Few People*

Small states, though few in people,
each hundred or ten has its leader,
people merely use tools yet do not serve the state.
They value death and do not flee far.

Though there are boats and chariots,
they have no use for them;
though there are armor and weapons,
they have no need to display them.
They return to using knotted cords for record-keeping.

They find their food sweet,
their clothing fine,
their dwellings secure,
their customs joyous.

Neighboring states are visible to one another,
the sounds of roosters and dogs heard between them.
People die of old age
without ever visiting one another.

The *sutra* says:
Small states, though few in people,
each hundred or ten has its leader,
people merely use tools yet do not serve the state.
They value death and do not flee far.

Though there are boats and chariots,
they have no use for them;
though there are armor and weapons,
they have no need to display them;

They return to using knotted cords for record-keeping.
Their food is sweet, their clothing fine,
their dwellings secure, their customs joyous.

Neighboring states lie in sight of one another,
the sounds of roosters and dogs heard across them,
yet people grow old and die
without ever knowing of public or private affairs between them.

The *Dao* says:
Tang ruled with seventy *li*, King Wen with a hundred *li*,
yet both held sway over the world—
both were small states with few people.

Thus, when boundaries were properly set
and the *jing* fields evenly distributed,
each commoner and housewife received a hundred *mu* of land,
and people were given leaders by tens and hundreds,
yet they did not lend or borrow from one another.

Then, the stipends of high, middle, and low officials were equalized,
and people were merely used as tools,
not conscripted for state service—
hence, "they are used as tools yet not for state purposes,"
leading people to value death and not flee far.

Though there are boats and chariots,
they have no place to go and ride them;
though there are armor and weapons,
they have no direction to deploy them;
they return to the ancient practice of knotted cords.

They till the fields and fish,
and their food is sweet.
They wear coarse hemp and bound shoes,
and their clothing is fine.
They dwell in caves and live in the wild,
and their homes are secure.
They drum their bellies and strike the earth,
and their customs are joyous.

Neighboring states lie in sight of one another,
the crowing of roosters and barking of dogs heard across them,
reaching to the four borders,
yet people grow old and die
without knowing of public or private affairs between them.

The *virtue/power* says:
Wealth and nobility bring security to the people—
this is when their *qi* is full and their *jing* abundant.
Small states with few people—
this is when their *qi* is weak and their *jing* depleted.

Though their *qi* is weak and their *jing* depleted,
there is still a way to restore decline and renew old age.
Up to a hundred and twenty years, one may yet return,
but beyond that, refining true sincerity becomes difficult—
one must rely on the nine-turns, eight-essence elixir,
the luminous essence of sun and moon to heal the aged and infirm—
how much more so for the small states with few people?

Those whose *qi* is weak and *jing* depleted
are the people who have exhausted the sixty-four *gua*.
They must first ensure each of the five *zang* and six *fu* has its master—
this is the *Yellow Court Inner Classic*.
Hence, "they have leaders by tens and hundreds."

Though one may set up furnaces and cauldrons,
it is merely for nurturing the medicine,
daring not to smelt, refine, or decoct—
hence, "they are used as tools yet not put to use."
They build elixir chambers and place cauldrons and vessels,
preserving them with care, using them sparingly,
so that people value death and do not flee far.

Though there are swift boats and racing chariots,
they have no place to ride them;
though there are strong armor and sharp weapons,
they have no direction to deploy them.

The people return to using knotted cords for reckoning.

This is called restoring the art of secure closure—
locks without bars that cannot be opened,
knots without cords that cannot be undone.
Is this not profound?

Thus, under Heaven’s great peace, one becomes a noble of the Primordial Sovereign,
delighting in their food, admiring their garments,
dwelling in ease, rejoicing in their customs,
where the Twelve Palaces address one another as *ér* and *rú* in forgetfulness.
Neighboring lands face each other,
the sounds of roosters and dogs intermingling—
the Twelve Channels harmonizing within and without.

If such harmony is attained,
until one’s natural end, with no further mingling with the vulgar world,
is this not fitting?

*"True words are not ornate"* (Chapter 81)
True words are not ornate; ornate words are not true.
The virtuous do not argue; those who argue are not virtuous.
The wise are not erudite; the erudite are not wise.
The sage does not hoard—
giving to others, the more they possess;
sharing with others, the more they have.

The Dao of Heaven benefits without harming;
The sage’s Dao acts without contention.
The Classic says:
True words are not ornate; ornate words are not true.
The virtuous do not argue; those who argue are not virtuous.
The wise are not erudite; the erudite are not wise.
The sage’s clarity is boundless—
what need has it for accumulation?
Giving to others, the more they possess;
sharing with others, the more they have.

The Dao of Heaven benefits without harming;
The sage’s Dao acts without contention.
The *Dao* declares:
When spoken, its flavor is faint and insipid.
When the Great Dao is abandoned, benevolence and righteousness arise;
When wisdom emerges, great deceit follows.
True words are not ornate.
Light promises bring few fulfillments;
many easy things bring many difficulties—
ornate words are not true.
All things rely on it to thrive yet it makes no claim;
when the work is done, it takes no credit—
the virtuous do not argue.
Its governance is subtle, yet its people are simple;
those who argue are not virtuous.
The wise do not speak; the wise are not erudite.
Those who speak are not wise; the erudite are not wise.

The sage’s Dao resides in the Supreme Ultimate,
a boundless clarity of *qi*, possessing all things—
thus it does not hoard.
Using this Dao for others, one’s own abundance increases;
sharing this Dao with others, one’s own wealth multiplies.
Thus, the Dao of Heaven benefits without harming—
none under Heaven can harm it.
The sage’s Dao acts without contention—
none under Heaven can contend with it.

*Virtue* declares:
True words are not ornate—this is the Great Dao of non-action.
Ornate words are not true—these are minor, tangential arts.
The virtuous do not argue—few are the words of the fortunate.
Those who argue are not virtuous—their words are many and hasty.
The wise are not erudite—they grasp the One through which all things pass.
The erudite are not wise—they rely on memorization and inquiry.

The sage’s Dao need not accumulate much—
the One generates the Two,
the Two generate the Three,
the Three generate all things—this suffices.

When this Dao is given to others,
others become oneself;
when all are oneself,
one’s own abundance grows.
When this Dao is shared with others,
others become oneself;
when all are oneself,
one’s own wealth multiplies.

Thus, the Dao of Primordial Heaven
benefits all under Heaven without harming others—
all clothe themselves in its teachings.
The sage’s Dao
acts for all under Heaven without contention—
all are adorned by its virtue.
When *Dao* and *virtue* clothe all under Heaven,
the achievements of the Primordial Sage are complete.

---
*[End of the Fourth Scroll of the Three Commentaries on the True Classic of Dao and Virtue]*

---
*[Annotations in original text]*
¹ *"以"* likely a corruption of *"易"* (ease/simplicity).
² *"轻敌"* (lightly regarding enemies)—original text omitted these characters.
³ *"东征西怨"*—likely *"东征西夷怨"* (lamentations of the Eastern and Western barbarians).
⁴ *"不敢为主而为客"*—original text omitted the second *"为"* (to be).
⁵ *"夫惟不厌，是以不厌"*—original text omitted *"是以不厌"* (thus it is not exhausted).
⁶ *"不得其死也坚强"*—*"死"* likely a corruption of *"生"* (life).
⁷ *"往而不入"*—likely *"无往而不入"* (nowhere it does not penetrate).
⁸ *"不贵於人"*—*"贵"* likely a corruption of *"责"* (to blame/reproach).

chunks.original_text: 道德真经三解 经名：道德真经三解。 元邓锜撰。 四卷。 底本出处：《正统道藏》洞神部玉诀类。 道德真经三解序 玉宾子邓锜撰 太上老君，四极真人也。 太者，大之极。 上者，高之极。 老者，寿之极。 君者，人之极。 故曰四极。 《周易》上经起於三，下经终於四，其卦六十四。 《道德》上经起於三，下经终於四，其章八十一。 《太玄》其方起於三，其家终於九，准《易》八十一首，道同德合矣。 河上公其不凡乎？ 老氏修道德，自隐无名，居周久之，遂去西游。 关令尹喜，大根器者也，先见其气，知有真人将至，物色候之。 遂识老氏於蒙尘之次，以为大道将隐，强请着书，近乎圣人也。 老氏亦知其奇，为言上下二经，大而无外，小而无内，圆而无周，方而无隅，是谓无始。 劫来天地，大道皆自圣人中出入，兼三才而两之也。 因知五千言者，皆於义皇心地上驰骋，无有辙迹。 苟以章句言之，又是周孔脚迹下盘旋，执着象物，何从而见道德乎？ 所以庄列之学，夸张雄辩； 申韩之学，专擅刑名；

*The Threefold Exegesis of the True Classic of the Dao and Its Virtue*
**Title:** *The Threefold Exegesis of the True Classic of the Dao and Its Virtue*
By Deng Qi of the Yuan Dynasty. Four fascicles.
Source text: *Daoist Canon of the Zhengtong Era*, *Washen* Section, Jade Instructions Category.

**Preface to *The Threefold Exegesis of the True Classic of the Dao and Its Virtue***
By Deng Qi, the Jade Guest

The Most High Lord Lao is the Perfected One of the Four Extremities.
*Tai* (Most) is the extremity of greatness.
*Shang* (High) is the extremity of loftiness.
*Lao* (Old) is the extremity of longevity.
*Jun* (Lord) is the extremity of humanity.
Thus, he is called the Four Extremities.

The *Zhouyi*’s Upper Canon begins with the number three, and its Lower Canon concludes with four, comprising sixty-four hexagrams.
The *Daode*’s Upper Canon begins with three, and its Lower Canon concludes with four, comprising eighty-one chapters.
The *Tai Xuan*’s directions commence with three, and its domains culminate in nine, aligning with the *Yi*’s eighty-one heads—Dao and virtue converge as one.

Was Master Heshang not extraordinary?
Laozi cultivated the Dao and its virtue, concealing himself in namelessness. Dwelling in Zhou for a long time, he eventually departed to wander westward. Guanling Yin Xi, a man of great capacity, perceived his qi in advance and knew a perfected one was approaching. He sought him out and awaited his arrival. Thus, he recognized Laozi amid the dust of the world, and believing the great Dao was about to withdraw, urgently entreated him to compose a text—an act akin to that of a sage. Laozi, recognizing his uniqueness, expounded the two canons, Upper and Lower. Vast yet without exterior, minute yet without interior, spherical yet without circumference, square yet without corners—this is called the Beginningless. Since the kalpas began, heaven and earth have seen the great Dao emerge and enter through the midst of sages, embracing the Three Powers and doubling them.

Thus, the five thousand words gallop across the primordial mind-ground of Fuxi, leaving no tracks. If one clings to chapter and verse, it becomes but a circling within the footprints of the Zhou and Confucius, grasping at images and things—how then can one perceive the Dao and its virtue? Hence, the learning of Zhuangzi and Liezi indulges in grandiloquence and eloquence, while the learning of Shen Buhai and Han Fei specializes in penal codes and names.

chunks.original_text: 王谢之学，假借玄谈。 又非仁者见之谓之仁，知者见之谓之知，此正谓五伯借虚名以取实利者也，安能见老氏之心乎？ 今以《周易》《论语》之暇，幸有余力，谨依《道德》章句，别 为三解，是知天地大，造化一，出於圣人，无为而为者矣，其旨不亦远乎？ 一解经曰：惟以正经句读增损一二虚字，使人先见一章正义，混然天成，无有瑕谪。 二解道曰：直述天地大道，始终原反，其数与理若合符节。 三解德曰：交索乾坤，颠倒水火，东金西木，结汞凝铅，一动一静，俱合大道。 凡五万余言，名曰《三解》。 《道德经》其经与《大易》准中，间有不得容心者矣，先圣后圣，其揆一也。 老氏一书，真常为主，解者悉与道德混而为一，不知宾主上下，以致诸儒妄生异议，无区以别矣。 今也先述真常三百字，以拟阴符之数，列于序次，庶使后之谈道德者不远迷其复矣。 四方证道之士，览而详之，苟有可取，容闻名於樵青足矣。 大德二年戊戌秋日玉宾子邓锜序。 真常三百字 真常之常，常谓之常； 常真之真，真谓之真。 真常在道，无所不抱； 真常在德，无所不则； 真常在命，无所不定； 真常在性，无所不应； 真常在理，无所不纪。 天地未始，真常真止； 天地既终，真常真空。 万物负阴而抱阳，圣人以之而有常； 大道能敝而不新，圣人以之而有真。 使真有形，无方而虚； 使常有名，无体而居。 道常无为而无不为，道真虚随而无以随。 圣人登极即真，与道合真。 上下无常，动静有常。 乾始能以美利利天下，不言其所利； 水能以美利利万物，不言其所德。 有为而为之失真，勿用之反常。 日月相推而明生，寒暑相推而岁成，是以真常无形名。 天道无言而告功，地道无成而代终，是以真常不虚空。 虚空相袭，天地无实； 无虚无实，复归无极； 无极无边，真常乃寂。 真常之寂，窈无所寂； 无寂之寂，真常乃息。 真常之息，窈无所息，无息之息，了不可得，了不可失，是以真常不虚息。 老子大传 老子者，楚苦县厉乡曲仁里人也。 姓李，名耳，字伯阳，谥曰聃，周守藏室之史也。 孔子适周，将问礼於老子。 曰：所言者，其人与骨皆已朽矣，独其言在耳。 且君子得其时则驾，不得其时则蓬累而行。 吾闻之，良贾深藏若虚，君子盛德，容貌若愚。 去子之骄气与多欲、态色与淫志，是皆无益於子之身。 吾所以告子，若是而已。 《家语□观周》又详。

chunks.original_text: 孔子去，谓弟子曰：鸟，吾知其能飞； 鱼，吾知其能游； 兽，吾知其能走。 走者可以为纲，游者可以为纶，飞者可以为矰。 至於龙，吾不能知，其乘风云而上天。 吾今日见老子，其犹龙邪？ 老子修道德，其学以自隐无名为务。 居周久之，见周之衰，遂去。 至关，关令尹喜曰：子将隐矣，强为我着书。 於是老子乃着书上下篇，言道德之意五千余言而去，莫知其所终。 或曰老莱子亦楚人也，着书十五篇，言道家之用，与孔子同时云。 盖老子百有六十余岁，或言二百余岁，以其修道而养寿也。 自孔子死之后百二十九年，而史记周太史檐见秦献公曰：始秦与周合而离，离五百岁而复合，合七十岁而霸王者出焉。 或曰儋即老子，或曰非也，世莫知其然否。 老子，隐君子也。 老子之子名宗，宗为魏将，封於段干。 宗子注，注子宫，宫玄孙假。 假仕於汉孝文帝。 时假之子解为胶西王昂大傅，因家于齐焉。 世之学老子者，则绌儒，儒学亦绌老子。 道不同不相为谋，岂谓耳邪？ 李耳无为自化，清静自正。 左仙公葛玄云：老氏周时复托神，李母剖左腋而生，生即皓然，号曰太上。 因玄而出在天地之先，无衰老之期，故曰太上，即三清化身也。 大道正统 夫玄宗之为教也，以清虚正一为宗，以长生不死为乐，故浮黎元始天尊，不知其几千万劫，方至三清。 又自三清，不知其几千万年，方且化身下降而为老子，以度真人尹喜，至仙卿李翼，凡十代，盖自周而汉也。 於是河上丈人出焉，自安期生凡九传而至三阳，则又迄乎五代之间矣。 一自三阳唱道以来，至於海蟾真人，传之张紫阳、王重阳。 紫阳传之翠玄，翠玄传之紫贤，紫贤传之翠虚，翠虚传之海琼，先生凡九传。 又王重阳真人之所传，凡七真，其间潜通默会，旁出普度，未究其几千万人。 若夫大道之正传，迄今海琼先生方三十五代尔。 惟上世先贤，享年度世，寿数极绵，年劫亦远，奥从中古，天不爱道，流布人间，度人无量，又不知所传至今凡几年劫也。 海琼而后，大道一脉归之鹤林先生，为往圣继绝学，为后世立法门，暇日因思所传之难，而究其自出，得其原委，以寿诸梓。 廷芝忝出鹤林先生门下一人之数，乃焚香再拜稽首而纪之。 庚申冬至日弟子萧廷芝书。 大道历数 浮黎元始天尊，即道生太极也。 下至玉清元始天尊，三万二千四百年，道生一也，故以天皇氏伏羲配之。 又一万八百年，至上清灵宝天尊，一生二也，故以地皇氏神农配之。 又一万八百年，至太清道德天尊，二生三也，故以人皇氏轩辕配之。 太清道德天尊与无上元君同时授先天大道，三生万物也，故以七十二师师广成子配之。 又一千九百年，至高上老子，是时慈尊亦生於世，万物负阴而抱阳，分阴分阳，两仪立焉，故以七十二贤师大圣人孔子配之。 冲气以为和，兼三才而两之也。 三教鼎足天下，而王公之道备矣，故曰：物或损之而益，益之而损。 人之所教，我亦教之。 强梁者不得其死，吾将以为教父。 大道历数，若合符节矣，正统原委，自有知者。 青城真人述。 道德真经三解卷之一 玉宾子邓锜述 道可道章第一 道可道，非常道，名可名，非常名。 无名，天地之始； 有名，万物之母。 常无，欲以观其妙；
