Thus, those who align with **Dao/Way**, **Dao/Way** is also theirs;
Those who align with **virtue/power**, **virtue/power** is also theirs;
Those who align with loss, loss is also theirs.
Yet still, faith is insufficient,
There will be doubt.
The **Dao/Way** says:
*The gusting wind and sudden rain—
This is what Heaven and Earth do,
Yet they cannot even last through the day.
How much less can man endure?
Heaven and Earth’s wind and rain,
Though gusting and sudden, have fixed measures.
Yet wind and rain cannot endure long—
This too is the natural Way of Heaven and Earth,
Hence, the Way of few words and naturalness.*

Therefore, those who follow this in **Dao/Way**,
Align with **Dao/Way** and **Dao/Way** is also theirs;
Those who follow this in **virtue/power**,
Align with **virtue/power** and **virtue/power** is also theirs;
Even those who follow this in loss,
Align with loss and loss is also theirs.
If faith is insufficient, doubt arises,
This is what is called:
*"To pass by in front and miss the mark,
To create false life and false death,
And thus decay like grass and wood—
Alas!"*

---

**Chapter Twenty-Four: The Lame Do Not Stand**
---

The lame do not stand,
The limping do not walk.
Those who self-illuminate are not clear,
Those who self-righteous are not manifest,
Those who self-praise achieve nothing,
Those who self-glorify do not endure.
In **Dao/Way**, this is called:
*"Excessive food and superfluous actions,
Things may detest them,
Thus, those in **Dao/Way** do not dwell here."*

The **Classics** say:
*"The foot limping cannot stand,
The thigh straddling cannot walk.
Those who self-illuminate are not clear,
Those who self-righteous are not manifest,
Those who self-praise achieve nothing,
Those who self-glorify do not endure.
In **Dao/Way**, this is called:
'The remnants of food, the excrescences of action,
Things may detest them,
Thus, those in **Dao/Way** do not dwell here.'"*

The **Dao/Way** says:
*"The one-eyed can see,
Yet cannot have true clarity;
The one-legged can tread,
Yet cannot truly walk—
How much less can the lame and the limping?"*

**Shun** opened the four gates,
Illuminated the four eyes,
Attained the four ears,
Thus, the **suffused fillets** closed his eyes—
*Not seeing yet seeing,*
The **earplugs** sealed his ears—
*Not manifest yet manifest.*
**Shun** also commanded **Yu**, saying:
*"You alone do not boast,
None under Heaven can contest your ability;
You alone do not praise yourself,
None under Heaven can contest your merit."*

In **Dao/Way**, this is called:
*"The remnants of action and inaction,
The excrescences of governance and morality,
Things may detest them—
Thus, those in **Dao/Way** do not dwell here."*

**Virtue/Power** says:
*"The lame do not stand—
This is the solitary purity and few stillness.
The limping do not walk—
This is the solitary yin and few yang.
How can they walk?"*

**Zi Yang** said:
*"One must know the Great Concealment dwells in the marketplace,
Do not merely hide in deep mountains to guard stillness in solitude."*

Thus:
*"Those who self-illuminate are not clear,
Those who self-righteous are not manifest,
Those who self-praise achieve nothing,
Those who self-glorify do not endure.
In **Dao/Way**, this is called:
'The remnants of food—
This is swallowing saliva and inhaling qi;
The excrescences of action—
This is sitting idle and inviting illness;
Things may detest them,
Thus, those in **Dao/Way** do not dwell here.'"*

---

**Chapter Twenty-Five: The Primordial Mixture**
---

There is a **Primordial Mixture** that coalesces,
Born before Heaven and Earth.
Silent and boundless,
It stands alone yet does not change,
Circulates endlessly yet does not falter,
It can be the **Mother of All under Heaven**,
I do not know its name—
Call it **Dao/Way**,
Forcefully name it **Great**.
**Great** means to pass,
To pass means to go far,
To go far means to return.
Thus, **Dao/Way** is **Great**,
Heaven is **Great**,
Earth is **Great**,
The **King** is also **Great**.
Within the realm, there are four **Great**,
And the **King** occupies one of them.
Man follows Earth,
Earth follows Heaven,
Heaven follows **Dao/Way**,
**Dao/Way** follows naturalness.

The **Classics** say:
*"There is a **Primordial Mixture** that coalesces,
Born before Heaven and Earth.
Silent and boundless,
It stands alone yet does not change,
Circulates endlessly yet does not falter,
It can be the **Mother of All under Heaven**,
The supreme treasure before Heaven and Earth.
I do not know its name—
Call it **Dao/Way**,
Forcefully name it **Great**.
**Great** must pass,
Passing must go far,
Going far must return—
The Way of returning to the original and completing the end.
Thus, **Dao/Way** is **Great**,
Heaven is **Great**,
Earth is **Great**,
The **King** is also **Great**.
Within the realm, there are four **Great**,
And the **King** occupies one of them—
The master of **Dao/Way**."*

chunks.original_text: 人法地，地法天，天法道，道法自然，道之神也。 道曰：太极之虚，中有神物，混然而成，先天地生而立两仪，寂兮寥兮於无有之乡，首出庶物之上，独立而不改其色，周行而不殆，实可以为天下万物之母，故圣人字之曰道，强名曰大。 大哉乾元，万物资始，乃统天。 云行雨施，品物流形。 大明终始，六位时成，故曰大。 大曰逝，逝曰远，远曰反，剥反为复之道也。 故道大，神无方而易无体也。 天大，天何言哉？ 四时行焉。 地大，地顺承天，百物生焉。 王亦大，天造草昧，宜建侯而不宁。 域中有四大，而王居其一焉，人之主也。 人法地，地法天，天法道，道法自然，人之用也。 大哉，圣人之言。 德曰：太极圈中，有一神物，可重一斤十六两零三百八十四铢，五千四十年又五千四十日而后结成，形如鸡卵，色似丹砂，明如皦日，味胜甘露，先天地而生，后天地而成，天地得之而生万物，圣人得之而生万民，虽寂寥独立而不改其变，虽周圆启行而不危其化，可以为天下民物之母，神乎神乎，故圣人字之曰道，强名曰大。 大则乃逝，逝则乃远，远则乃反，不远复也。 天以始生，言之自上而下，王亦主之；
chunks.translated_text:
「The human follows Earth, Earth follows Heaven, Heaven follows **Dao/Way**, **Dao/Way** follows naturalness—**Dao/Way** is the divine essence.

**Dao/Way** speaks:
*"Within the **Supreme Ultimate**'s void (*太极之虚*), there exists a divine substance (*神物*), coalescing in **Primordial Mixture** (*混然而成*), born before Heaven and Earth yet establishing the **Two Principles** (*两仪*). Silent and boundless in the realm of **Non-existence** (*无有之乡*), it emerges as the first among all things (*庶物*), standing alone yet unchanging in its essence (*色*), circulating endlessly without faltering (*周行而不殆*). Indeed, it can be the **Mother of All under Heaven** (*万物之母*), so the Sage names it **Dao/Way** and forcefully calls it **Great** (*大*).

**Great** indeed is the **Primordial Mixture** (*乾元*)! All things derive their beginning from it—thus it unifies Heaven. Clouds move and rain falls, and all things take shape in their forms (*品物流形*). The **Great Brightness** (*大明*) completes the beginning, and the six positions (*六位*) of time are thus formed—hence it is called **Great**.

**Great** means to pass (*逝*), passing means to go far (*远*), going far means to return (*反*), and the **Way** of returning after **shedding and renewal** (*剥反*) is **restoration**.

Thus, **Dao/Way** is **Great**—the divine essence has no bounds, and **Ease** (*易*) has no fixed form (*体*). Heaven is **Great**—how can it be spoken of? The four seasons move therein. Earth is **Great**—it follows and sustains Heaven, and all things grow therefrom. The **King** is also **Great**—Heaven created the **primitive chaos** (*草昧*), and it is fitting to establish **feudal lords** (*侯*) yet it remains restless. Within the realm, there are four **Great**—and the **King** occupies one of them, the master of humanity.

The human follows Earth, Earth follows Heaven, Heaven follows **Dao/Way**, **Dao/Way** follows naturalness—this is the **application** (*用*) of humanity.

**Great** indeed are the words of the Sage!

**Virtue/Power** (*德*) speaks:
*"Within the **Supreme Ultimate**'s circle (*太极圈中*), there exists a divine substance (*神物*), weighing one **jin** (*斤*) sixteen **liang** (*两*), zero three hundred and eighty-four **zhu** (*铢*), which takes five thousand four hundred and forty years and five thousand four hundred and forty days to coalesce (*结成*). Its form is like a chicken’s egg, its color resembles cinnabar (*丹砂*), its brilliance matches the **radiant sun** (*皦日*), its taste surpasses **sweet dew** (*甘露*). It is born before Heaven and Earth yet completes itself after them. Heaven and Earth obtain it and give birth to all things; the Sage obtains it and gives birth to all people. Though silent and boundless, it stands alone yet does not alter its transformations (*变*), though it circulates fully and begins to act (*启行*), it does not endanger its **manifestations** (*化*). It can be the **Mother of All under Heaven** (*天下民物之母*)—divine, how divine! So the Sage names it **Dao/Way** and forcefully calls it **Great** (*大*).

**Great** means it must pass (*逝*), passing means it must go far (*远*), going far means it must return (*反*)—yet it does not return far. Heaven, in its beginning of creation (*始生*), speaks from above to below, and the **King** is its master as well."*

chunks.original_text: 地以既成，言之自下而上，王亦主之。 天地生成者，道也。 王中主者之心也，圣人穷理尽性以至於命矣。 重为轻根章第二十六 重为轻根，静为躁君。 是以君子终日行不离辎重。 虽有荣观，燕处超然。 如何万乘之主，而以身轻天下。 轻则失臣，躁则失君。 经曰：重者，轻之根也。 静者，躁之君也。 是以君子终日行而不附离於辎重。 所以万乘之主而以身轻天下，则不失其臣也。 虽有荣观，燕处超然。 躁则不失其君也。 以轻为事，必失其臣； 以躁为事，必失其君。 道曰：合抱之木，生於毫末，重为轻之根也。 清静为天下正，静为躁之君也。 是以君子终日行不附辎重，恐为轻躁所累。 虽有荣观，以重观轻也。 燕处超然，以静胜躁也。 如何万乘之主，而以身轻天下。 盖一身重者，轻之根蒂也。 万乘之静者，躁之君主也。 夫轻者，枝叶也。 重者，根本也。 以外物言之，本乎天者亲上，枝叶在上，故轻为重之君，本乎地者亲下，根本在下，故重为轻之臣。 若执轻而行之，则必失重臣，故曰轻则失臣。 以万乘言之，静者无为也，躁者有为也。 我无为而民自化，无为在上，故静为躁之君，我有为而民自乱，有为在下，故躁为静之臣。 若执躁而行之，则叉失静君，故曰躁则失君。 文乎，老子之言矣。 德曰：纯阳有云：道本虚无一炁，生天生地生人，都来些子气精神，造化不离玄牝。 玄牝之门，是谓天地根，故重为轻根。 正阳有云：妙法三千六百门，学人各执一为根，谁知些子神仙法，不在三千六百门，故曰静为躁君。 是以君子终日行不离辎重，亦犹万乘之君以身轻天下也。 虽有荣观，一念不动也。 燕处超然，心境两忘也。 轻则失臣，基址不固，有伤至药也。 躁则失君，火候太过，有伤元阳也。 善行无辙迹章第二十七 善行无辙迹，善言无瑕谪，善计不用筹策，善闭无关键而不可开，善结无绳约而不可解。 是以圣人常善救人，故无弃人； 常善救物，故无弃物。 是谓袭明。 故善人，不善人之师； 不善人，善人之资。 不贵其师，不爱其资，虽智大迷，是谓要妙。 经曰：不见辙迹，可谓善行。 不见瑕商，可谓善言。 不用筹策，可谓善计。 善闭无关键而不可开，善结无绳约而不可解。 是以圣人以常善救人，故无弃人，以常善救物，故无弃物。 此谓相袭而明也。 故善人者，不善人之师； 不善人者，善人之资。 不以善人贵其师，不以不善爱其资，虽曰智慧，谓之大迷，既智返迷，是谓要妙。 道曰：春夏秋冬，天之四府，善行无辙迹也。 《易》、《书》、《诗》、《春秋》，圣人四府，善言无瑕请也。 生长收藏，善计不用筹策也。 坤以藏之，善闭无关键而不可开也。 乾以君之，善结无绳约而不可解也。 是以圣人以天地常道救人，故无弃人，以天地常道救物，故无弃物。 是谓相袭而明也。 何谓袭明？ 故善人乃不善人之师，不善人乃善人之资，非袭明而何？ 不以不善贵其师，不以善人爱其资，虽有大知，亦曰大迷，反乎朴素，是谓要妙。 德曰：日用践履，无辙可逵。 口传心受，无瑕可请。 依时探取，不用筹策，可谓善计。 殊无关键而不可开，可谓善闭。 殊无绳约而不可解，可谓善结。 此无为清静之道也。 是以圣人常善救人，人有道，故无弃人；

**Chapter Twenty-Six: "Heavy as the Root of Light"**
Heavy serves as the root of light; stillness is the sovereign of agitation.
Thus, the virtuous person moves all day without straying from his baggage train.
Though adorned with splendid sights, he rests in serene detachment.
How can the ruler of ten thousand chariots bear the weight of the world lightly?
Lightness loses his ministers; agitation loses his sovereignty.

The Classic says:
*"Heavy is the root of light; stillness is the sovereign of agitation."*
Thus, the virtuous person moves all day without straying from his baggage train—
so that the ruler of ten thousand chariots may bear the world lightly without losing his ministers.
Though adorned with splendid sights, he rests in serene detachment—
so that agitation may not overthrow his sovereignty.

To act with lightness is to lose his ministers;
to act with agitation is to lose his sovereignty.

The **Dao/Way** says:
*"A tree as thick as an embrace begins as a tiny sprout—
heavy is the root of light.
Purity and stillness govern all under Heaven—
stillness is the sovereign of agitation."*

Thus, the virtuous person moves all day without straying from his baggage train,
fearing to be burdened by lightness and agitation.
Though adorned with splendid sights, he observes lightness through heaviness.
He rests in serene detachment, conquering agitation through stillness.

How can the ruler of ten thousand chariots bear the world lightly?
For a heavy body is the foundation of lightness;
a still ruler of ten thousand chariots is the sovereign of agitation.

Lightness is but branch and leaf;
heaviness is root and foundation.
Speaking of external things:
What originates from Heaven clings to the upper—
branches and leaves are above, so lightness is the sovereign of heaviness.
What originates from Earth clings to the lower—
roots and foundations are below, so heaviness is the minister of lightness.

If one clings to lightness in action, he will surely lose his heavy ministers—
thus it is said: *"Lightness loses his ministers."*
Speaking of the ruler of ten thousand chariots:
Stillness is non-action; agitation is action.
If I act with non-action, the people transform themselves;
non-action above, so stillness is the sovereign of agitation.
If I act with action, the people fall into disorder;
action below, so agitation is the minister of stillness.

If one clings to agitation in action, he will surely lose his still sovereign—
thus it is said: *"Agitation loses his sovereignty."*

The **Virtue/Power** says:
*"Pure Yang declares:
The **Dao/Way** originates from emptiness and non-being, a single breath (*qi*).
It generates Heaven, Earth, and humankind—
all from this vital essence and spirit.
Creation never departs from the Mysterious Female.
The Mysterious Female’s gate is called the root of Heaven and Earth—
thus, heavy is the root of light.

True Yang declares:
The wondrous **Dharma** has three thousand six hundred gates;
each practitioner clings to one as root.
Who knows the true method of immortality?
It lies not in the three thousand six hundred gates—
thus, stillness is the sovereign of agitation."*

Thus, the virtuous person moves all day without straying from his baggage train—
just as the ruler of ten thousand chariots bears the world lightly.
Though adorned with splendid sights, his mind remains undisturbed.
He rests in serene detachment, forgetting both self and environment.

Lightness loses his ministers—
the foundation is unstable, harming the supreme elixir.
Agitation loses his sovereignty—
the fire’s intensity is excessive, harming the primal yang.

---
**Chapter Twenty-Seven: "The Virtuous Walk Leaves No Tracks"**
The virtuous walk leaves no tracks;
virtuous speech has no flaws;
virtuous planning requires no calculations;
virtuous closure needs no locks yet cannot be opened;
virtuous binding needs no cords yet cannot be undone.

Thus, the Sage constantly aids people, so none are abandoned;
constantly aids things, so none are discarded.
This is called *"inheriting clarity."*

Therefore, the good person is the teacher of the unvirtuous;
the unvirtuous are the resources of the good.
To not honor one’s teacher, to not cherish one’s resources—
though wise, this is called great confusion.
This is called *"the essential mystery."*

The Classic says:
*"No tracks are seen—this is called virtuous walking.
No flaws are seen—this is called virtuous speech.
No calculations are used—this is called virtuous planning.
Virtuous closure needs no locks yet cannot be opened;
virtuous binding needs no cords yet cannot be undone."*

Thus, the Sage constantly aids people, so none are abandoned;
constantly aids things, so none are discarded.
This is called *"inheriting clarity."*

Therefore, the good person is the teacher of the unvirtuous;
the unvirtuous are the resources of the good.
To not honor the good as one’s teacher,
to not cherish the unvirtuous as one’s resources—
though called wisdom, it is great confusion.
To return to simplicity after confusion—
this is called *"the essential mystery."*

The **Dao/Way** says:
*"Spring, summer, autumn, and winter—
Heaven’s four treasuries—
this is virtuous walking leaving no tracks.
The *Book of Changes*, *Book of Documents*, *Book of Poetry*, and *Spring and Autumn Annals*—
the Sage’s four treasuries—
this is virtuous speech with no flaws.
Growth, decline, harvest, and storage—
this is virtuous planning requiring no calculations.
The Receptive (*Kun*) conceals it—
this is virtuous closure needing no locks yet unopenable.
The Creative (*Qian*) governs it—
this is virtuous binding needing no cords yet unbreakable."*

Thus, the Sage aids people with Heaven and Earth’s eternal **Dao/Way**,
so none are abandoned;
aids things with Heaven and Earth’s eternal **Dao/Way**,
so none are discarded.
This is called *"inheriting clarity."*

What is *"inheriting clarity"*?
If not this, what is it?
To not honor the unvirtuous as one’s teacher,
to not cherish the good as one’s resources—
though one may possess great wisdom,
it is still called great confusion.
To return to simplicity—
this is called *"the essential mystery."*

The **Virtue/Power** says:
*"Daily practice leaves no tracks to follow.
Oral transmission, heart-to-heart—no flaws to request.
Following the seasons to take what is needed—
no calculations are used; this is called virtuous planning.
Without locks yet unopenable—this is called virtuous closure.
Without cords yet unbreakable—this is called virtuous binding.
This is the **Dao/Way** of non-action and stillness."*

Thus, the Sage constantly aids people—
people have the **Dao/Way**, so none are abandoned;

**Great** means it must pass (*逝*), passing means it must go far (*远*), going far means it must return (*反*)—yet it does not return far. Heaven, in its beginning of creation (*始生*), speaks from above to below, and the **King** is its master as well."*

chunks.original_text: 常善救物，物有道，故无弃物。 是谓人物相袭而明，天地之大道也。 故善人袭不善人以为资，不善人袭善人以为师，遂使善与不善俱有大得，亦不贵其师，亦不爱其资，故人无弃人，物无弃物，智而复迷，迷而复智，是谓妙道之要也。 知其雄章第二十八 知其雄，守其雌，为天下溪。 为天下溪，常德不离，复归於婴儿。 知其白，守其黑，为天下式。 为天下式，常德不忒，复归於无极。 知其荣，守其辱，为天下谷。 为天下谷，常德乃足，复归於朴。 朴散则为器，圣人用之则为官长，故大制不割。 经曰：知雄守雌，为天下溪。 守雌为溪，常德不离。 合德不离，复归於婴儿。 知白守黑，为天下式。 守黑为式，常德不忒。 合德不忒，复归於无极。 知荣守辱，为天下谷。 守辱为谷，常德乃足，合德乃足，复归於朴。 散则为器，圣人用之则为主官，故大制不割，害其朴也。 道曰：知其雄，守其雌，乾知太始，坤作成物也，故为天下溪。 地道无成而代有终也，故曰常德不离。 冬至一阳，复生坎震，故曰复归於婴儿。 知其白，守其黑，战乎乾，劳乎坎，金水相生也，故为天下式。 十二辟卦生成万物也，故曰常德不忒。 十月坤藏，复归於无极也。 知其荣，守其辱，否泰相交，损益盛衰之始也，故为天下谷。 离终于寅，坎终于申，故曰常德乃足。 成终成始，复归於朴。 形而上者谓之道，形而下者谓之器，故曰朴散则为器。 圣人居中履正，以为万物之主，故大制不割。 复归於朴，而又原始反终矣。 德曰：知雄守雌，以木克金，以汞制铅，金木间膈，汞铅相制，二气捆缊，聚於一道，故为天下溪。 是以常德不离，养成婴儿。 知白守黑，白为他人，黑属自己，主其他人之白，守其自己之黑，故为天下式。 是以常德不忒，复归於无极。 十月，坤道也。 知荣守辱，荣金辱木，常德不足，知其金之荣，守其木之辱，故为天下谷。 是以常德乃足，复归於朴。 朴散则为器，主器者莫若长子，是以圣人用之则为官长，故大制不割。 散之斯为万，合之斯为一也，神乎神乎。 将欲取天下章第二十九 将欲取天下而为之，吾见其不得已。 天下神器，不可为也。 为者败之，执者失之。 故物或行或随，或煦或吹，或强或羸，或载或隳。 是以圣人去甚，去奢，去泰。 经曰：将欲取天下而为之者，吾见其不得已也。 天下神器，不可为也。 为者必败之，执者必失之。 凡在天下之物，或行或随，各有一时； 或煦或吹，各有一气； 或强或羸，各有一势； 或载或隳，各有一道。 是以圣人去甚，去奢，去泰。 道曰：取天下者，常以无事，及其有事，不足以取天下。 古之得天下无为而治者，真有为也。 将欲取天下而为之，吾见其不得已，故天下神器，不可妄为也，为者败之，执者失之。 凡物行之随之，各有天时； 煦之吹之，各有气数； 强之羸之，各有势力； 载之隳之，各有道理。 是以圣人去其甚，不使不得已，去其奢，不使有败，去其泰，不使有失。 德曰：天之有天下，犹人之有身也。 人身之事，亦有自然可取之时，将欲取而为之者，吾见其不得已。 况天下人身，乃上天之神器，断不可以为也。 取而为者必败，执而取者必失之。 凡人之为物，行者随之以时，煦者吹之以气，强者赢之以势，载者隳之以理。
chunks.translated_text:
常善救物，物有道，故无弃物。
Thus, the Sage constantly aids all things—
all things have the **Dao/Way**, so none are abandoned;

是谓人物相袭而明，天地之大道也。
This is called *"inheriting clarity"* between humans and things,
the grand **Dao/Way** of heaven and earth.

故善人袭不善人以为资，不善人袭善人以为师，
Thus, the virtuous **inherits clarity** from the unvirtuous as their resources,
and the unvirtuous **inherits clarity** from the virtuous as their teachers,
遂使善与不善俱有大得，
thereby allowing both the virtuous and the unvirtuous to attain great understanding,
亦不贵其师，亦不爱其资，
yet neither honors their teacher nor cherishes their resources.
故人无弃人，物无弃物，
Hence, people abandon no one, and all things are aided.
智而复迷，迷而复智，
Wisdom returns to confusion, and confusion returns to wisdom—
是谓妙道之要也。
this is called the essential mystery of the wondrous **Dao/Way**.

**知其雄章第二十八**
The **Chapter on Knowing the Masculine** (28):

知其雄，守其雌，为天下溪。
Know the **masculine** (*yang*) and hold to the **feminine** (*yin*), to become the **Dao/Way** of the world’s **valley** (*xī*).

为天下溪，常德不离，复归於婴儿。
To become the **valley** of the world,
the Sage’s **virtue/power** remains unbroken,
returning to the state of the **infant** (*yīng’ér*).

知其白，守其黑，为天下式。
Know the **white** and hold to the **black**, to become the world’s **model** (*shì*).

为天下式，常德不忒，复归於无极。
To become the world’s **model**,
the Sage’s **virtue/power** is never excessive,
returning to the **limitless** (*wújí*).

知其荣，守其辱，为天下谷。
Know the **glory** and hold to the **humiliation**, to become the world’s **valley** (*gǔ*).

为天下谷，常德乃足，复归於朴。
To become the world’s **valley**,
the Sage’s **virtue/power** is then complete,
returning to **simplicity** (*pǔ*).

朴散则为器，圣人用之则为官长，
**Simplicity** (*pǔ*) disperses to become **vessels** (*qì*).
The Sage employs it to become the **chief minister** (*guānzhǎng*),
故大制不割。
thus the great **principle** (*zhì*) is not severed.

经曰：
The **Classic** says:
知雄守雌，为天下溪。
Know the **masculine** and hold to the **feminine**, to become the world’s **valley**.
守雌为溪，常德不离。
To hold to the **feminine** as the **valley**,
the Sage’s **virtue/power** remains unbroken.
合德不离，复归於婴儿。
When **virtue/power** is not severed, it returns to the **infant**.
知白守黑，为天下式。
Know the **white** and hold to the **black**, to become the world’s **model**.
守黑为式，常德不忒。
To hold to the **black** as the **model**,
the Sage’s **virtue/power** is never excessive.
合德不忒，复归於无极。
When **virtue/power** is not excessive, it returns to the **limitless**.
知荣守辱，为天下谷。
Know the **glory** and hold to the **humiliation**, to become the world’s **valley**.
守辱为谷，常德乃足，
To hold to the **humiliation** as the **valley**,
the Sage’s **virtue/power** is then complete,
合德乃足，复归於朴。
when **virtue/power** is complete, it returns to **simplicity**.
散则为器，圣人用之则为主官，
When dispersed, it becomes **vessels**;
the Sage employs it as the **chief minister**,
故大制不割，害其朴也。
thus the great **principle** is not severed—
this would damage **simplicity**.

道曰：
The **Dao/Way** says:
知其雄，守其雌，
Know the **masculine** and hold to the **feminine**,
乾知太始，坤作成物也，
for the **Heavenly** (*Qián*) **virtue/power** knows the **beginning** (*tàishǐ*),
and the **Earthly** (*Kūn*) **virtue/power** completes all things.
故为天下溪。
Thus, it becomes the world’s **valley**.
地道无成而代有终也，
The **Earthly** **Dao/Way** has no fixed end but cycles through completion.
故曰常德不离。
Hence, it is said that the Sage’s **virtue/power** remains unbroken.
冬至一阳，复生坎震，
At the **winter solstice** (*dōngzhì*), the **masculine** (*yīng*) emerges,
and the **Water** (*Kǎn*) and **Thunder** (*Zhèn*) trigrams are reborn.
故曰复归於婴儿。
Thus, it is said to return to the **infant**.
知其白，守其黑，
Know the **white** and hold to the **black**,
战乎乾，劳乎坎，
for the **Heavenly** (*Qián*) **virtue/power** is in **strife** (*zhàn*),
and the **Water** (*Kǎn*) **virtue/power** is in **toil** (*láo*),
金水相生也，
as the **Metal** (*Jīn*) and **Water** (*Shuǐ*) trigrams generate one another.
故为天下式。
Thus, it becomes the world’s **model**.
十二辟卦生成万物也，
The twelve **transformative** (*bì*) hexagrams generate all things.
故曰常德不忒。
Hence, it is said that the Sage’s **virtue/power** is never excessive.
十月坤藏，复归於无极也。
In the tenth month, the **Earthly** **virtue/power** conceals itself,
returning to the **limitless**.
知其荣，守其辱，
Know the **glory** and hold to the **humiliation**,
否泰相交，
as the **dark** (*pǐ*) and **bright** (*tài*) phases intermingle,
损益盛衰之始也，
marking the **beginning** of **growth** (*yì*) and **decline** (*shuāi*).
故为天下谷。
Thus, it becomes the world’s **valley**.
离终于寅，坎终于申，
The **Fire** (*Lí*) phase ends at the **Tiger** (*yín*) hour,
and the **Water** (*Kǎn*) phase ends at the **Monkey** (*shēn*) hour.
故曰常德乃足。
Hence, it is said that the Sage’s **virtue/power** is then complete.
成终成始，复归於朴。
When completion ends and **beginning** begins again,
it returns to **simplicity**.
形而上者谓之道，
The **formless** (*xíng’érshàng*) is called the **Dao/Way**,
形而下者谓之器，
the **formed** (*xíng’érxià*) is called **vessels**.
故曰朴散则为器。
Thus, it is said that **simplicity** disperses to become **vessels**.
圣人居中履正，
The Sage dwells in the **center** (*zhōng*), walking in **rectitude** (*lǚzhèng*),
以为万物之主，
to serve as the **master** of all things.
故大制不割。
Thus, the great **principle** is not severed.
复归於朴，
Returning to **simplicity**,
而又原始反终矣。
it again **reverts to the origin** and **returns to the end**.

德曰：
The **Virtue/Power** says:
知雄守雌，
Know the **masculine** and hold to the **feminine**,
以木克金，
for **Wood** (*Mù*) overcomes **Metal** (*Jīn*),
以汞制铅，
and **Mercury** (*Gǒng*) restrains **Lead** (*Qiān*),
金木间膈，
as **Metal** and **Wood** are **interposed** (*jiāngè*).
汞铅相制，
And **Mercury** and **Lead** restrain one another,
二气捆缊，
binding the two **qi** (*qì*) forces,
聚於一道，
into unity with the **Dao/Way**.
故为天下溪。
Thus, it becomes the world’s **valley**.
是以常德不离，
Hence, the Sage’s **virtue/power** remains unbroken,
养成婴儿。
nurturing the **infant**.
知白守黑，
Know the **white** and hold to the **black**,
白为他人，黑属自己，
for the **white** belongs to others,
and the **black** belongs to oneself.
主其他人之白，
To **master** the **white** of others,
守其自己之黑，
and hold to the **black** of oneself,
故为天下式。
thus, it becomes the world’s **model**.
是以常德不忒，
Hence, the Sage’s **virtue/power** is never excessive,
复归於无极。
returning to the **limitless**.
十月，坤道也。
The tenth month is the **Earthly** **Dao/Way**.
知荣守辱，
Know the **glory** and hold to the **humiliation**,
荣金辱木，
for **glory** is **Metal** (*Jīn*) and **humiliation** is **Wood** (*Mù*).
常德不足，
The Sage’s **virtue/power** is not yet complete,
知其金之荣，
knowing the **glory** of **Metal**,
守其木之辱，
and holding to the **humiliation** of **Wood**,
故为天下谷。
thus, it becomes the world’s **valley**.
是以常德乃足，
Hence, the Sage’s **virtue/power** is then complete,
复归於朴。
returning to **simplicity**.
朴散则为器，
**Simplicity** disperses to become **vessels**,
主器者莫若长子，
and none can **master** **vessels** like the **eldest son** (*zhǎngzǐ*).
是以圣人用之则为官长，
Thus, the Sage employs it to become the **chief minister**,
故大制不割。
thus the great **principle** is not severed.
散之斯为万，合之斯为一也，
When dispersed, it becomes the **ten thousand** (*wàn*),
when united, it becomes **one** (*yī*).
神乎神乎。
Mysterious indeed, mysterious!

**将欲取天下章第二十九**
The **Chapter on Seeking to Take the World** (29):

将欲取天下而为之，
When one seeks to take the world and **acts** upon it,
吾见其不得已。
I see that it is not inevitable.
天下神器，
The world is a **divine vessel** (*shénqì*),
不可为也。
which cannot be **acted upon**.
为者败之，
To **act** upon it is to **defeat** it,
执者失之。
and to **grasp** it is to **lose** it.
故物或行或随，
Thus, all things either **move** (*xíng*) or **follow** (*suí*),
或煦或吹，
either **warm** (*xù*) or **chill** (*chuī*),
或强或羸，
either **strong** (*qiáng*) or **weak** (*léi*),
或载或隳，
either **bear** (*zài*) or **destroy** (*huī*).
是以圣人去甚，去奢，去泰。
Hence, the Sage avoids the **excessive** (*shèn*),
the **extravagant** (*shē*), and the **overbearing** (*tài*).

经曰：
The **Classic** says:
将欲取天下而为之者，
When one seeks to take the world and **acts** upon it,
吾见其不得已也。
I see that it is not inevitable.
天下神器，
The world is a **divine vessel**,
不可为也。
which cannot be **acted upon**.
为者必败之，
To **act** upon it is to **defeat** it,
执者必失之。
and to **grasp** it is to **lose** it.
凡在天下之物，
All things under heaven
或行或随，
either **move** or **follow**,
各有一时；
each has its **time** (*shí*).
或煦或吹，
either **warm** or **chill**,
各有一气；
each has its **qi** (*qì*).
或强或羸，
either **strong** or **weak**,
各有一势；
each has its **force** (*shì*).
或载或隳，
either **bear** or **destroy**,
各有一道。
each has its **Dao/Way**.
是以圣人去甚，去奢，去泰。
Hence, the Sage avoids the **excessive**, the **extravagant**, and the **overbearing**.

道曰：
The **Dao/Way** says:
取天下者，
Those who seek to take the world
常以无事，
should **do nothing** (*wúshì*).
及其有事，
But when they **act**,
不足以取天下。
it is insufficient to take the world.
古之得天下无为而治者，
The ancients who obtained the world through **non-action** (*wúwéi*) and **governance** (*zhì*)
真有为也。
were truly **acting** (*yǒuwéi*).
将欲取天下而为之，
When one seeks to take the world and **acts** upon it,
吾见其不得已，
I see that it is not inevitable.
故天下神器，
Thus, the world is a **divine vessel**,
不可妄为也，
which cannot be **acted upon** recklessly.
为者败之，
To **act** upon it is to **defeat** it,
执者失之。
and to **grasp** it is to **lose** it.
凡物行之随之，
All things **move** or **follow**,
各有天时；
each has its **heavenly time**.
煦之吹之，
either **warm** or **chill**,
各有气数；
each has its **allotted qi** (*qìshù*).
强之羸之，
either **strong** or **weak**,
各有势力；
each has its **strength** (*shìlì*).
载之隳之，
either **bear** or **destroy**,
各有道理。
each has its **principles** (*dàolǐ*).
是以圣人去其甚，
Hence, the Sage avoids the **excessive**,
不使不得已，
so that it is not inevitable.
去其奢，
avoids the **extravagant**,
不使有败，
so that there is no **defeat**.
去其泰，
avoids the **overbearing**,
不使有失。
so that there is no **loss**.

德曰：
The **Virtue/Power** says:
天之有天下，
Heaven’s possession of the world
犹人之有身也。
is like a person’s possession of their **body** (*shēn*).
人身之事，
The affairs of a person’s **body**
亦有自然可取之时，
also have their **natural** (*zìrán*) times when they can be **taken**.
将欲取而为之者，
When one seeks to **take** and **acts** upon it,
吾见其不得已。
I see that it is not inevitable.
况天下人身，
Much more so for the world and the people’s **bodies**,
乃上天之神器，
which are the **divine vessels** of the **Highest Heaven** (*shàngtiān*).
断不可以为也。
they cannot be **acted upon** at all.
取而为者必败，
To **take** and **act** upon them is to **defeat** oneself,
执而取者必失之。
and to **grasp** and **take** them is to **lose** them.
凡人之为物，
All things in the world of people
行者随之以时，
either **move** or **follow** in their **time**,
煦者吹之以气，
either **warm** or **chill** with their **qi**,
强者赢之以势，
either **strong** or **weak** with their **force**,
载者隳之以理。
either **bear** or **destroy** with their **principles**.
chunks.overlap_context:
**Virtue/Power** says:
*"Daily practice leaves no tracks to follow.
Oral transmission, heart-to-heart—no flaws to request.
Following the seasons to take what is needed—
no calculations are used; this is called virtuous planning.
Without locks yet unopenable—this is called virtuous closure.
Without cords yet unbreakable—this is called virtuous binding.
This is the **Dao/Way** of non-action and stillness."*

Thus, the Sage constantly aids people—

chunks.original_text: 是以圣人去甚，去奢，去泰，非以其无私邪？ 故能成其私。 以道佐人主章第三十 以道佐人主者，不以兵强天下，其事好还。 师之所处，荆棘生焉。 大军之后，必有凶年。 故善者果而已，不敢以取强。 果而勿矜，果而勿伐，果而勿骄，果而不得已，是果而勿强。 物壮则老，是谓不道，不道早已#1。 经曰：以道佐人主者，不以兵强取天下，其事好还。 师之所处，荆棘生焉。 大军之后，必有凶年。 故善佐人主者，果於道而已矣，不敢以取强。 果而勿伐，果而勿骄，果而不得已者胜，乃是果而勿强也。 盖物壮则老，是谓非道。 如知非道，不如早已。 道曰：公卿以道佐人主，不以兵强天下，人主以道佐天地，不以暴政害物。 泰象曰：天地交，泰。 后以财成天地之道，辅相天地之宜，以左右民。 故得道者多助，失道者寡助。 多助之至，天下顺之，寡助之至，亲戚畔之。 以天下之所顺，攻亲戚之所畔，故君子有不战，战必胜矣，不以兵强也。 苟以兵强天下，其事必然好还。 师之所处，荆棘生焉。 大军之后，必有凶年。 天道好还也。 临之二阳，至于八月，有凶是矣。 故善战者果於道而已矣，不敢以兵取强焉，取强必败。 苟得其果而勿矜、勿伐、勿骄而不得已，是果而勿强，何哉？ 盖物壮则老，是谓非道。 如知非道，不如早已。 德曰：人主，心也。 以道治心者，恬淡为上，不敢以战胜之兵而取天下。 太阳流味，长欲去人，故天发杀机，龙蛇起陆，人发杀机，天地反覆，其事必然好还。 天摇地动，山崩谷裂，树倒林摧，河枯海竭，岂非师之所处，荆棘生焉，大军之后，必有凶年乎？ 真可畏也，故善战者果於道而已矣。 果得其道不已，何为复敢以取强为？ 所以不矜、不伐、不骄，长若不得已，乃是果而不敢强。 何则？ 用壮处谦，壮乃全矣，用壮羝触藩矣。 谓物壮而不已则老，此谓非道。 知其非道，早已勿为。 夫佳兵章第三十一 夫佳兵者，不祥之器，物或恶之，故有道者不处。 是以君子居则贵左，用兵则贵右。 兵者，不祥之器，非君子之器，不得已而用之，恬淡为上。 胜而不美，而美之者，是乐杀人。 夫乐杀人者，不可得志於天下。 是故吉事尚左，凶事尚右。 偏将军处左，上将军处右，言以丧礼处之？ 杀人众多，以悲哀泣之，故战胜则亦以丧礼处之。 经曰：夫以兵为佳者，不祥之器也，物或恶之，故有道者不处。 是以君子居则贵左，主生也。 用兵则贵右#2，主杀也。 兵者不祥之器，非君子之器，不得已而用之者，须以恬淡为上。 故胜而不知为美也，若以为美，必乐之，乐之者，是乐杀人也。 夫乐杀人者，人必杀之，不可得志於天下矣。 故吉事尚左，凶事尚右。 偏将军处左，不主杀也。 上将军处右，言居上势，则以丧礼处之。 杀人众多，以悲哀泣之，故战胜则亦以丧礼处之。 道曰：师，众也。 贞，正也。 能以众正，可以王矣。 至於刚中而应，行险而顺，以此毒天下而民从之吉，民苟不从，何凶无之？ 故兵之佳者，尚为不祥之器，而况於取强乎？ 物或恶之矣，故有道者不处也。 是以君子居则贵左，帝出于震，春生以仁也，故吉事尚左。 是以偏将军处左，六四师左次，则以吉礼处之。 用兵则贵右，王革乎兑，秋杀以义也，故凶事尚右。

**Chapter Thirty: Assisting the Sovereign with the Dao**
Those who assist the sovereign with the Dao do not use force of arms to compel the world; their actions return to them as they sow. Where the army encamps, brambles and thorns grow. After great armies march, there will surely be years of famine. Thus, the virtuous are resolute in the Dao alone, daring not to rely on force. Resolute yet unboastful, resolute yet unvaunting, resolute yet unarrogant, resolute yet without compulsion—this is to be resolute without relying on force. When things flourish, they grow old; this is called *not-Dao*. *Not-Dao* brings early ruin#1.

The Classic says: Those who assist the sovereign with the Dao do not use force of arms to take the world; their actions return to them as they sow. Where the army encamps, brambles and thorns grow. After great armies march, there will surely be years of famine. Thus, those skilled in assisting the sovereign are resolute in the Dao alone, daring not to rely on force. Resolute yet unvaunting, resolute yet unarrogant, resolute yet without compulsion—this is to be resolute without relying on force. Things flourish then grow old; this is called *not-Dao*. If one knows it is *not-Dao*, it is better to cease early.

The Dao says: Ministers and nobles assist the sovereign with the Dao, not using force of arms to compel the world. The sovereign assists Heaven and Earth with the Dao, not using violent governance to harm beings. The *Tai* hexagram speaks: "Heaven and Earth unite—*Tai*. The sovereign completes Heaven and Earth’s Dao, aids their natural order, and governs the people accordingly. Thus, those who hold the Dao gain much assistance; those who lose the Dao gain little. When assistance is at its peak, the world follows them; when it is at its lowest, even kin betray them. To attack where the world follows and where kin betray—thus, the virtuous may have no war, yet if they war, they must win, not relying on force.

If one relies on force of arms to compel the world, their actions will surely return to them as they sow. Where the army encamps, brambles and thorns grow. After great armies march, there will surely be years of famine. The Dao of Heaven returns as it sows. When the two *yang* lines are ascendant, reaching the eighth month, disaster is certain. Thus, those skilled in war are resolute in the Dao alone, daring not to rely on force of arms, for relying on force leads to defeat. If one attains resoluteness yet remains unboastful, unvaunting, unarrogant, and without compulsion—this is to be resolute without relying on force. Why? For things flourish then grow old; this is called *not-Dao*. If one knows it is *not-Dao*, it is better to cease early.

The *De* says: The sovereign is the heart. Those who govern the heart with the Dao hold tranquility and simplicity as supreme, daring not to use the weapons of victory to seize the world. The Great Yang flows with its flavor, longing to depart from humanity, so Heaven unleashes its killing intent, and dragons and serpents rise from the earth. When humanity unleashes its killing intent, Heaven and Earth reverse their course, and their actions will surely return to them as they sow. Heaven shakes, Earth trembles, mountains collapse, valleys split, trees fall, forests crumble, rivers dry, seas exhaust—is this not where the army encamps, brambles and thorns grow, and after great armies march, there will surely be years of famine? Truly terrifying! Thus, those skilled in war are resolute in the Dao alone. If one attains the Dao and does not cease, why would they dare to rely on force? Thus, they do not boast, do not vaunt, do not grow arrogant, yet endure as if compelled—this is to be resolute without relying on force. For when strength is used in humility, strength is preserved; if strength is used recklessly, it will meet ruin. It is said: things flourish yet do not cease, they grow old—this is called *not-Dao*. Knowing it is *not-Dao*, cease early.

**Chapter Thirty-One: The Fine Weapon**
The fine weapon is an ominous instrument; beings detest it, so those who hold the Dao do not dwell upon it. Thus, the virtuous in peace value the left, in war value the right. The weapon is an ominous instrument, not the instrument of the virtuous; it is used only when unavoidable, with tranquility and simplicity held supreme. To win yet not take pride in victory—if one takes pride, they delight in killing. Those who delight in killing cannot fulfill their ambitions in the world. Thus, auspicious matters are honored on the left, inauspicious on the right. The Assistant General stands left, not mastering killing; the Supreme General stands right, signifying a position of dominance, treated with funeral rites. Many are slain, and with sorrowful weeping—thus, even in victory, they are treated with funeral rites.

The Classic says: To call arms a fine weapon is to speak of an ominous instrument; beings detest it, so those who hold the Dao do not dwell upon it. Thus, the virtuous in peace value the left—life’s side—and in war value the right#2—death’s side. The weapon is an ominous instrument, not the instrument of the virtuous; it is used only when unavoidable, with tranquility and simplicity held supreme. Thus, to win yet not regard it as beautiful—if one regards it as beautiful, they will delight in it, and delighting in it is to delight in killing. Those who delight in killing, others will surely kill them; they cannot fulfill their ambitions in the world. Thus, auspicious matters are honored on the left, inauspicious on the right. The Assistant General stands left, not mastering killing. The Supreme General stands right, signifying a position of dominance, treated with funeral rites. Many are slain, and with sorrowful weeping—thus, even in victory, they are treated with funeral rites.

The Dao says: The army is the multitude. *Zhen* is rectitude. To govern the multitude with rectitude is to attain kingship. When firm yet yielding, moving through peril yet following the natural order—with this, one poisons the world, yet the people follow, bringing auspice. If the people do not follow, what disaster is there? Thus, even the fine weapon is an ominous instrument, much less relying on force! Beings detest it, so those who hold the Dao do not dwell upon it. Thus, the virtuous in peace value the left, for the Emperor emerges from *Zhen*—spring’s birth with benevolence—so auspicious matters are honored on the left. Thus, the Assistant General stands left, the fourth line of the *Shi* hexagram placing the army on the left, treated with auspicious rites. In war, the right is valued, for the *Wang* hexagram is linked to *Yi*—autumn’s killing with righteousness—so inauspicious matters are honored on the right.

chunks.original_text: 是以上将军处右，言居上势，则以丧礼处之。 兵者不祥之器，非君子之器也，不得已而用之者，必以恬淡虚无为上，故不为美也。 若以兵为美事，必如秦楚而乐杀人也。 夫乐杀人者，不可得志於天下，悉归于炎汉矣。 故杀人众多，以悲哀泣之，故数战数胜，亦以丧礼处之。 德曰：纯阳有云：吾有三剑而斩世人之欲。 紫阳云：先且观天明五贼，次须察地以安民，民安国富当求战，战罢方能见圣人。 此最兵之佳者，亦为不祥之器，有物或恶之者，故有道者不处。 是以君子居则贵左，知雄守雌，以养木液也。 用兵则居右，知白守黑，以取金液也。 取则有道，不以兵强取之。 兵者，不祥之器，非君子之器，如不得已而用之，恬淡为上。 故不以兵为美，美而乐之，是杀人之利器也。 夫乐杀人者，其事必好还，不可得志於天下矣。 是以偏将军处左，故以吉礼处之，上将军处右，故以丧礼处之。 好斗者必通其敌，可不慎哉。 道常无名章第三十二 道常无名，朴虽小，天下不敢臣。 侯王若能守，万物将自宾。 天地相合，以降甘露，人莫之令而自均。 始制有名，名亦既有。 夫亦将知止，知止所以不殆。 譬道之在天下，犹川谷之与江海。 经曰：道常无名，其朴虽小，天下不敢臣。 侯王若能守之，万物将自宾矣。 故天地相合，以降甘露，人莫之令而物自均。 始制有名，物既有名亦将知止，知止所以不殆。 譬如道之在天下，亦由川谷之与江海也。 道曰：道常无名，天地之始也。 始制有名，万物之母也。 其朴虽小，乃道常之一，天下谁敢臣之？ 故王侯得一以为天下正，若能守之，万物将自宾矣。 天地相合，以降甘露，故兑者说也，以形普沾於万物之上，而为发生之利泽，岂人力之为哉，而物自均矣。 始制有名也，名既遂矣，亦将知止，知止所以不殆。 夫道之於天下，天下虽大，皆归于道。 江海之於川谷，川谷虽众，皆赴於江海。 侯王之於万物，万物虽殊，皆宾於侯王。 有名而不知止者，恶乎何归？ 德曰：其道与常，本无名字，先天一气也。 形质虽小，天下谁敢臣之？ 侯王，人身之主也，若能守此先天一气，不以为小，则身中万事万物自宾服矣。 故天地絪缊，万物化醇，男女媾精，万物化生，聚精会神，以降甘露，人莫之令而自均，复归於婴儿。 始制有名也，名亦既有，夫亦将知止，不敢有为，为则殆矣，故曰知止所以不殆。 夫万物皆归于人身，譬犹天下皆归于道，川谷皆归于江海矣，岂不大哉。 知人者智章第三十三 知人者智，自知者明。 胜人者有力，自胜者强。 知足者富，强行者有志。 不失其所者久，死而不亡者寿。 经曰：知人者智，自知者明。 胜人者有力，自胜者乃强。 知足者长富，强行者有志。 居不失其所者能久，身死而名不亡者为寿。 道曰：道人胸中自有水镜，万象起灭，无逃其形。 水主智，知人者智也。 圣人之道，克己复礼，知常容乃公，公生明，自知者明也。 吉凶者，贞胜者也。 至於以强凌弱，以众暴寡，胜人者有力也。 一日克己复礼，天下归仁焉，自胜者强也。 富莫大於知足，祸莫大於不知足，责莫大於知止，殆莫大於不知止。 知足者，富也。 君子以自强不息，有志也。 并居其所而不迁，而不失其所者，恒久之道也。

Thus, the Supreme General stands on the right, signifying a position of dominance, and is treated with funeral rites. War is an ominous instrument, not the tool of the virtuous. When used unavoidably, one must hold to serenity, simplicity, and emptiness as supreme—thus, it is not glorified. If war is taken as a noble pursuit, it will surely become like Qin and Chu, delighting in slaughter. Those who delight in slaughter cannot prevail in the world; their fate belongs to the flames of Han.

Thus, though many victories are won, they are mourned with sorrowful tears. Hence, even repeated battles and repeated triumphs are treated with funeral rites.

**Virtue says:** Pure Yang declares: *"I have three swords to sever the desires of the world."* Purple Yang says: *"First, observe the Five Bandits of Heaven’s clarity; next, examine the Earth to settle the people. When the people are at ease and the nation is wealthy, then seek battle. Only after war’s end may one behold the Sage."* This is the finest of war’s instruments, yet still an ominous tool, which beings may detest. Thus, those who follow the Dao do not dwell upon it.

Therefore, the virtuous in peace honor the left, knowing to embrace the yielding while guarding the firm—nurturing the essence of wood. In war, they stand on the right, knowing to embrace the dark while guarding the bright—seeking the essence of metal. Taking must follow the Way; one does not seize by force. War is an ominous instrument, not the tool of the virtuous. If used unavoidably, serenity is supreme. Thus, war is not glorified; to glorify it is to wield a tool of slaughter. Those who delight in slaughter will meet ruin—how can they prevail in the world?

Hence, the Assistant General stands left, treated with auspicious rites, while the Supreme General stands right, treated with funeral rites. Those who love strife must know their enemy—how can one be too cautious?

**Chapter 32: The Dao Ever Nameless**
The Dao ever nameless,
Though its simplicity is small,
The world dares not submit to it.

If lords and kings can guard it,
All things will come as guests.

Heaven and Earth unite,
Descending sweet dew—
No one commands, yet all is balanced.

When names first arise,
Names already exist.

Knowing when to stop,
Stopping is how one avoids peril.

Compare the Dao in the world
To rivers and valleys flowing to the sea.

The Classic says:
*The Dao ever nameless,
Though its simplicity is small,
The world dares not submit to it.
If lords and kings can guard it,
All things will come as guests.*

Thus, Heaven and Earth unite,
Descending sweet dew—
No one commands, yet all is balanced.
When names first arise,
Things already named will know when to stop.
Knowing when to stop is how one avoids peril.

Compare the Dao in the world
To rivers and valleys flowing to the sea.

**The Dao says:**
The Dao ever nameless,
Is the beginning of Heaven and Earth.
When names first arise,
It becomes the mother of all things.
Though its simplicity is small,
It is the constant of the Dao—
Who dares submit to it?

Thus, lords and kings who hold to it
Upright the world.
If they can guard it,
All things will come as guests.

Heaven and Earth unite,
Descending sweet dew—
Thus, the receptive rejoices,
Its form universally nourishing all things above,
Bringing the benefit of birth.
Who could attribute this to human effort?
Yet all is balanced.

When names first arise,
Names already exist—
One must know when to stop.
Knowing when to stop is how one avoids peril.

The Dao in the world—
Though the world is vast,
All return to the Dao.
Rivers and valleys to the sea—
Though many, all flow to the sea.
Lords and kings to all things—
Though diverse, all submit.

Those who name yet do not know when to stop—
Where shall they return?

**Virtue says:**
Its Dao is ever constant,
Originally nameless—
The One Qi before Heaven.
Though its form is small,
Who dares submit to it?

Lords and kings are the masters of the body—
If they guard this One Qi before Heaven,
Not deeming it small,
Then all affairs and things within the body submit.

Thus, Heaven and Earth interweave,
All things refine into purity,
Male and female merge their essence,
All things generate,
Gathering essence and spirit,
Descending sweet dew—
No one commands, yet all is balanced,
Returning to the infant state.

When names first arise,
Names already exist—
One must know when to stop.
To act is perilous—
Thus, it is said: *Knowing when to stop is how one avoids peril.*

All things return to the human body—
Like the world returning to the Dao,
Rivers and valleys to the sea—
Is it not vast?

---
**Chapter 33: Knowing Others is Wisdom**
Knowing others is wisdom;
Knowing oneself is enlightenment.
Overcoming others is strength;
Overcoming oneself is power.

Knowing contentment is wealth;
Persistent action is resolve.
Not losing one’s place ensures longevity;
Dying yet not perishing is true life.

The Classic says:
*Knowing others is wisdom;
Knowing oneself is enlightenment.
Overcoming others is strength;
Overcoming oneself is power.
Knowing contentment ensures lasting wealth;
Persistent action is resolve.
Dwelling without losing one’s place ensures endurance;
Dying yet leaving a name unvanquished is true life.*

**The Dao says:**
The Dao within the breast is like a mirror of water—
All forms arise and vanish without escaping its reflection.
Water governs wisdom; knowing others is wisdom.

The Sage’s Dao:
Conquering the self to restore propriety,
Knowing the constant to embrace the public—
Publicness generates enlightenment;
Knowing oneself is enlightenment.

Auspicious and inauspicious are determined by the steadfast victor.

As for the strong oppressing the weak,
The many assaulting the few—
Overcoming others is strength.

One day conquering the self to restore propriety,
The world returns to benevolence—
Overcoming oneself is power.

Wealth knows no greater than contentment;
Calamity knows no greater than ignorance of contentment.
Blame knows no greater than ignorance of stopping;
Peril knows no greater than ignorance of stopping.

Knowing contentment is wealth.
The virtuous persist without ceasing—they have resolve.
Dwelling in their place without shifting,
Not losing their place—
This is the constant of endurance.

chunks.original_text: 豫六五贞，疾，恒不死，中未亡也。 虽亡而寿者，恒不死之道也。 德曰：知己知彼，百战百胜； 不知彼而知己，一胜一负； 不知己不知彼，百战百败。 凡养生之道，必以阴阳互为其基，轻重不敢偏失，先要知人，后要知己，不知不明，阴阳偏失，如何成事？ 胜人者不在有力，自有道理。 自胜者却在有力，自无道理。 既有其名，亦将知止，故知足者长富。 如此力行而不倦者，有志之士也。 进退消长，抽添运用而不失其所者，可谓恒久而不已也。 虽没而不殆，虽死而不亡，坐在立亡，形神俱妙，可谓恒寿而不已也。 大道泛兮章第三十四 大道泛兮，其可左右。 万物恃之以生而不辞，功成不名有。 爱养万物而不为主，常无欲，可名於小； 万物归之而不为主，可名於大。 是以圣人终不为大，故能成其大。 经曰：大道泛兮，无可左右。 万物恃之以生而不有辞，功成不名有。 覆载万物而亦不为主，故常无欲，此可名於小矣。 万物归之而不知主，此可名於大矣。 是以圣人终不为大，故能成其大。 道曰：以万物观天地，则天地之谓天地，以道观天地，则天地亦万物耳。 故大道泛兮，皆是无可左右者。 故物恃之以生而亦不有辞，万物家之以成而亦不为主，功成亦不有名。 故常无欲，卷之不盈握，此皆名於小矣。 万物归之而不知主，散之弥六合，此可名於大矣。 是以圣人能成其大也，终不以为大，故能成其大。 天地设位，圣人成能，人谋鬼谋，百姓与能。 德曰：太极大道泛兮，周行一百万八千里，包乎天地六十四万里，升降於三万里之中，迎之不见其音，随之不见其后，其可以左右乎？ 天地万物恃之以生，其道何辞？ 天地万物赖之以成，其道何主？ 以气言之，其称名也小，以物言之，其取类也大。 是以圣人提挈天地之道，把握阴阳之气，以一元为一年，以一年为一日，以一日为一时，夺造执於须臾，成大功於顷刻，然后洗心防思，退藏於密，故曰是以圣人能成其大也。 执大象章第三十五 执大象，天下往。 往而不害，安平泰。 乐与饵，过客止。 道之出言，淡乎其无味。 视之不足见，听之不足闻，用之不可既。 经曰：无象之象，是谓大象。 执往天下，有何害矣，岂止不害，安且平泰。 乐与人饵，过客亦止。 道之为言，淡乎其无味。 视之不足见，听之不足闻，及用之亦不可尽既。 道曰：惚兮恍，其中有象，圣人执而行之，虽往天下，不为害矣，以其安平且泰，皇建其有极也。 无偏无陂，遵王之义，无有作好，遵王之道，无有作恶，遵王之路。 无偏无党，王道荡荡； 无党无偏，王道平平； 无反无侧，王道正直。 会其有极，归其有极，故乐与百姓饵之，遂使有过之客无不知其止矣。 夫道之出其言，淡乎其无味，又非中边皆甜，吾千退席也。 视之不足见，不可用明焉； 听之不足闻，不可用聪焉。
chunks.translated_text:
The **Sixth Five** in *Yù*—auspicious and steadfast—
Though swift, its constancy endures;
Its core remains unlost.
Though lost, yet long-lived—
This is the Way of the unending.

**Virtue** speaks:
Know thyself, know thy foe,
A hundred battles, a hundred victories.
Know thy foe not, yet know thyself,
One victory, one defeat.
Know neither self nor foe,
A hundred battles, a hundred defeats.

The Way of nurturing life
Must root in yin and yang’s interplay,
Light and weight balanced—
Never erring.
First, know others;
Then, know thyself.
Without knowing, how can one discern?
If yin and yang are skewed,
How can deeds be wrought?

Conquering others lies not in brute force—
It has its own logic.
Conquering oneself lies not in brute force—
It has no logic at all.

Having a name, one must know when to stop;
Thus, the contented endure in wealth.

To persist without ceasing—
This is the resolve of the virtuous.
Advancing, retreating, waxing, waning,
Drawing, adding—
Using all without losing ground—
This is the unending Way.

Though fallen, yet no peril;
Though dead, yet not lost.
Sitting, life; standing, death—
Form and spirit both refined—
This is the unending longevity.

---
**Chapter Thirty-Four: The Great Dao Flows**

The Great Dao flows—
It cannot be confined to left or right.
All things rely on it to live,
Yet it claims no credit.
Its work is done without taking ownership,
Ever without desire—
This is called *small*.
All things return to it,
Yet it takes no ownership—
This is called *great*.
Thus, the Sage never claims greatness,
And so achieves greatness.

The Classic says:
The Great Dao flows—
It cannot be confined to left or right.
All things rely on it to live,
Yet it claims no credit.
Its work is done without taking ownership,
Ever without desire—
This is called *small*.
All things return to it,
Yet it takes no ownership—
This is called *great*.
Thus, the Sage never claims greatness,
And so achieves greatness.

The Dao speaks:
Observe all things through Heaven and Earth,
And Heaven and Earth are but Heaven and Earth.
Observe them through the Dao,
And Heaven and Earth are but all things.
Thus, the Great Dao flows—
All is beyond left or right.
All things rely on it to live,
Yet it claims no credit.
All things complete through it,
Yet it takes no ownership.
Its work is done without taking credit.
Ever without desire,
It can be rolled up yet never fills the hand—
This is called *small*.
All things return to it,
Yet it knows no master—
This is called *great*.
Thus, the Sage achieves greatness,
Yet never claims it,
And so achieves greatness.

Heaven and Earth set their places,
The Sage perfects their functions.
Human schemes, ghostly schemes—
The people’s power is their strength.

**Virtue** speaks:
The Great Ultimate, the Great Dao flows—
Circulating a million eighteen thousand *li*,
Encompassing Heaven and Earth’s sixty-four thousand *li*,
Ascending and descending within three thousand *li*.
Approaching, no sound is heard;
Following, no trace remains—
How can it be confined to left or right?
All things rely on it to live—
What claim does its Way make?
All things depend on it to complete—
What mastery does its Way hold?
Speaking of *qi*,
Its name is small;
Speaking of things,
Its kind is vast.
Thus, the Sage grasps Heaven and Earth’s Way,
Holds yin and yang’s *qi*,
Making one *yuan* a year,
One year a day,
One day a moment—
Seizing creation in an instant,
Achieving great deeds in a breath,
Then cleansing the heart, guarding the mind,
Retreating into seclusion—
Thus, the Sage achieves greatness.

---
**Chapter Thirty-Five: Grasping the Great Symbol**

Grasp the Great Symbol,
And all under Heaven will follow.
Following without harm,
Peace and ease prevail.
Offer joy and bait,
Even passing travelers will stay.
The Dao’s utterance is bland—
Tasteless, yet profound.
Gazed upon, not fully seen;
Listened to, not fully heard;
Used, never exhausted.

The Classic says:
The Symbol without form—
This is called the Great Symbol.
Grasp it, and all under Heaven follows—
What harm could there be?
Not just no harm—
Peace and ease prevail.
Offer joy and bait to the people,
Even passing travelers will stay.
The Dao’s utterance is bland—
Tasteless, yet profound.
Gazed upon, not fully seen;
Listened to, not fully heard;
Used, yet never fully exhausted.

The Dao speaks:
Mysterious and vague—
Yet within, a Symbol.
The Sage grasps it and acts,
And though all under Heaven follows,
No harm is done—
For it brings only peace and ease,
Establishing its ultimate.
Without bias or favor,
It follows the King’s righteousness;
Without artificial goodness,
It follows the King’s Way;
Without artificial evil,
It follows the King’s path.
Without bias or faction,
The King’s Way is vast;
Without faction or bias,
The King’s Way is level;
Without reversal or deviation,
The King’s Way is straight.
Gathering at its ultimate,
Returning to its ultimate—
Thus, offering joy and bait to the people,
Even passing travelers know to stop.
The Dao’s utterance is bland—
Not sweet on the edges or the center.
Gazed upon, not fully seen—
Not to be grasped by sight;
Listened to, not fully heard—
Not to be grasped by hearing.

chunks.original_text: 是以圣人取诸十三卦象，备物玫用，立成器以为天下利，百姓日用而不知，故曰用之不可既。 德曰：大象，先天之道也。 圣人执之而往天下，不有害矣。 是以得道之士，刀锯不能加，水火不能伤，何害之有哉？ 以其神形既安，心情既平，性命既泰也。 故以此象乐与天下饵之，虽有大过之客，亦反身而知止矣。 何则知其大象可执也。 夫大象之道，出言无味，饵亦无味，视之不可见，听之不可闻，及其用之，大有神效，不可既尽。 将欲翕之章第三十六 将欲翕之，必固张之；

The Sage takes the symbols of the thirteen *guà* (trigrams), exhaustively gathering and refining their uses,
To create perfect instruments for the benefit of all under Heaven—
The common people employ them daily without knowing their source,
Thus it is said: *"Their use cannot be fully exhausted."*

**Virtue/power** states: *"The Great Symbol*—the Dao/Way of the Primordial*—is the Sage’s guide.
When the Sage holds it and acts in the world,
No harm shall come—
Thus, those who grasp the Dao/Way
Are unharmed by blade or saw,
Nor scorched by water or fire—
What harm could they know?
For their spirit and form are at ease,
Their heart and *qì* (vitality) are balanced,
Their nature and life are in perfect harmony.

Therefore, with this Great Symbol,
The Sage offers joy and nourishment to all under Heaven—
Even those with grave transgressions
Turn back and know to cease.

Now why do they know to hold fast to the Great Symbol?
The Dao/Way of the Great Symbol
Speaks without taste,
Nourishes without taste—
Gazed upon, it is unseen;
Listened to, it is unheard—
Yet when put to use,
Its effects are wondrous beyond measure,
Inexhaustible in their power.

**When one seeks to contract**—*Chapter Thirty-Six*:
**When one seeks to contract,**
One must first expand.

chunks.original_text: 将欲弱之，必固强之； 将欲废之，必固兴之； 将欲夺之，必固与之。 是谓微明。 柔胜刚，弱胜强。 鱼不可脱於渊，国之利器，不可以示人。 经曰：张之必翕，强之必弱，兴之必废，夺之必与。 将欲如此得之，必固如此失之，是谓微而明也。 柔胜刚，弱胜强。 若鱼刚强，不可脱於柔弱之渊。 故国家利器，亦不可以示人。 道曰：内文明而外柔顺，以蒙大难，文王以之。 利艰贞，晦其明也。 内难而能正．其志，箕子以之。 故月不晦则不明，爽不昧则不旦，天不寒则不暑，地不藏则不生，天地造物之权也。 至如东作西成，民利百倍，百姓之权也。 可与立未可与权，圣人深器之。 柔之胜刚，弱之胜强，若鱼龙不可脱於渊，是谓先微而后着也。 是知柔弱渊源，江海之利器也，固不可以见怪，见怪则殆。 张强兴与，国家之利器也，固不可以示人，示人则危。 几事不密，则害成也必矣。 德曰：知雄守雌，为天下溪。 知白守黑，为天下式。 道者盗也，三盗既宜。 德者得也，一得为度。 大抵修炼者，人为也。 虽曰人为，静为躁君，阴阳须配合，火候要调停。 嗡弱废夺而在我者，故静以待动； 张强兴与而在人者，故动以随静。 此谓幽微而着明也。 万物生于水而归于水，水至柔弱，鱼龙不可以脱於渊也。 人至刚强，不可以脱于天一之水。 故国之利器，不可以示人，轻易示人，必致凶害。 人之至宝，不可以示人，轻易示人，必遭谴谪。 此天地圣人之权，非纵横牌阖之语也明矣。 道常无为章第三十七 道常无为而无不为，侯王若能守，万物将自化。 化而欲作，吾将镇之以无名之朴。 无名之朴，亦将不欲。 不欲以静，天下将自正。 经曰：道常无为，而无不为也。 侯王若能守，万物将自化。 化而欲作，不知无为，吾将镇之以无名之朴。 无名之朴，亦将不欲。 不欲惟以静，静则天下将自正。 道曰：道本无为，常本无欲，无为无欲，而无不为无不欲也。 侯王若能守之，万物将自化矣。 黄帝尧舜，垂衣裳而天下治，无为而治也。 夫何为哉？ 恭己正南面而已矣，故曰我无为，民自化。 化之欲作，又恐专於有为，吾将镇之以无名之朴。 道常无为也，夫无名之朴亦将不欲。 以治天下欲者，守之以静，静则天下将自正矣。 德曰：道常无为，清静法身也，而无不为矣。 侯王若能守之以道，万物将自化。 生化而欲作，吾将镇之以无名之朴。 先天大药也，先天大朴亦岂所欲。 欲而不欲，惟守以静，天下性命将自正矣。 道常无为而为，真有为也。 有为而为，必不至如此之妙。 道德真经三解卷之二竟 #1 不道早已：『不道』二字原脱。 #2 用兵则贵右：『兵』字原脱。 道德真经三解卷之三 玉宾子邓锜述

**When one seeks to weaken**—
One must first strengthen;
When one seeks to discard,
One must first exalt;
When one seeks to take,
One must first give.

This is called *subtle clarity*.
The soft overcomes the hard,
The weak overcomes the strong.

Fish cannot escape the depths,
Nor can a state’s sharpest tools
Be shown to all.

The Classic says:
To stretch is to contract,
To strengthen is to weaken,
To exalt is to discard,
To take is to give.

If one would thus attain,
One must thus lose—
This is called *subtle yet clear*.

The soft overcomes the hard,
The weak overcomes the strong.
If fish are rigid and strong,
They cannot escape the yielding depths.

Thus, a state’s sharpest tools
Must not be displayed to all.

The Dao says:
Within, clarity and refinement,
Without, softness and compliance—
To endure great peril,
As did King Wen.

*Difficult virtue stands firm*—
Hiding its brilliance.

Within, turmoil yet steadfast resolve—
As did Ji Zi.

Thus, the moon, veiled, shines brighter,
The dawn, obscured, arrives clearer,
The sky, not cold, brings summer’s heat,
The earth, concealed, nurtures life—
The sovereign power of Heaven and Earth.

As for eastward labor and westward harvest,
A hundredfold gain for the people—
The people’s sovereign power.

With some, one may stand;
With others, one must yield—
The Sage treasures this deeply.

The soft overcomes the hard,
The weak overcomes the strong—
Like fish and dragons, they cannot escape the depths.
This is called *first subtle, then manifest*.

Thus, the depths of softness and weakness—
The treasures of river and sea—
Must not be revealed lightly,
For revelation brings peril.

Strengthening, exalting, giving, taking—
The state’s sharpest tools—
Must not be displayed to all,
For display brings danger.

If schemes are not kept secret,
Disaster will surely arise.

*Virtue says*:
Know the male yet cling to the female—
This is the valley of all under Heaven.
Know the white yet cling to the black—
This is the model for all under Heaven.

The Dao is a thief—
Three thefts are fitting.
*Virtue* is attainment—
One attainment is the measure.

In essence, cultivation is human effort.
Though called human effort,
Stillness rules the restless,
Yin and yang must align,
Fire and timing must be balanced.

What is weak, discarded, taken away—
If held within,
Then stillness awaits movement;
What is strong, exalted, given—
If in others,
Then movement follows stillness.

This is called *subtle yet manifest*.

All things arise from water and return to water.
Water is supremely soft and weak—
Yet fish and dragons cannot escape the depths.

Humans, at their most rigid and strong,
Cannot escape the *Heavenly One’s* water.

Thus, a state’s sharpest tools
Must not be displayed to all—
Lightly shown, they bring ruin.
A person’s greatest treasure
Must not be displayed to all—
Lightly shown, they invite censure.

This is the sovereign power of Heaven, Earth, and the Sage—
Not the rhetoric of *strategic maneuvering*.

**Chapter Thirty-Seven: The Dao/Way of Constant Non-Action**

The Dao/Way constantly does nothing
Yet nothing remains undone.
If lords and kings could uphold it,
All things would transform of themselves.

When transformation stirs to act,
I will restrain it with the *Nameless Primordial*.
The *Nameless Primordial*
Will also refuse to act.

By not desiring, one attains stillness—
Then all under Heaven will align itself.

The Classic says:
The Dao/Way constantly does nothing
Yet nothing remains undone.
If lords and kings could uphold it,
All things would transform of themselves.

When transformation stirs to act,
And they do not know non-action,
I will restrain it with the *Nameless Primordial*.
The *Nameless Primordial*
Will also refuse to act.
By not desiring, one attains stillness—
Stillness, and all under Heaven will align itself.

The Dao says:
The Dao/Way is originally non-action,
Its root is non-desire.
Non-action and non-desire—
Yet nothing remains undone or undesired.

If lords and kings could uphold it,
All things would transform of themselves.

The Yellow Emperor, Yao, and Shun
Wore simple robes,
Yet all under Heaven was governed—
Governed through non-action.

What need for action?
Only reverence and rectitude in the southern face—
Thus it is said: *I do nothing, yet the people transform themselves.*

When transformation stirs to act,
Again, lest they lean toward action,
I will restrain it with the *Nameless Primordial*.

The Dao/Way is constant non-action—
The *Nameless Primordial* will also refuse to act.
To govern those who desire,
One must hold to stillness—
Stillness, and all under Heaven will align itself.

*Virtue says*:
The Dao/Way is constant non-action—
The pure, still body—
Yet nothing remains undone.

If lords and kings could uphold it with the Dao/Way,
All things would transform of themselves.

When transformation stirs to act,
I will restrain it with the *Nameless Primordial*—
The *Primordial Medicine of the Pre-Heaven*—
The *Primordial Primordial* is not what is desired.

Desiring yet not desiring—
Only by holding to stillness
Will the nature and life of all under Heaven align itself.

The Dao/Way constantly does nothing yet does—
This is true action.
Action through action
Cannot reach such subtlety.

*The Three Teachings of the Dao/Way and Virtue Classic, Volume Two, ends here.*

chunks.original_text: 上德不德章第三十八 上德不德，是以有德，下德不失德，是以无德。 上德无为而无以为，下德为之而有以为。 上仁为之而无以为，上义为之而有以为。 上礼为之而莫之应，则攘臂而仍之。 故失道而后德，失德而后仁，失仁而后义，失义而后礼。 夫礼者，忠信之薄而乱之首也。 前识者，道之华而愚之始。 是以大丈夫处其厚不处其薄，居其实不居其华，故去彼取此。 经曰：上德不患失，是以有德。 下德患失，是以无德。 上德无为而无有以为，下德为之而有以为也。 上仁为之而无以为，德与之应。 上义为之而有以为，仁与之应。 上礼为之而义莫之应矣，岂止不应，则又攘臂而仍之。 故失道而后德，失德而后仁，失仁而后义，失义而后礼。 夫礼者，以其忠信之薄而为乱之首也。 前识先觉者，道之华而反为愚之始。 是以大丈夫处其厚不处其薄，居其实不居其华，故去彼取此。 道曰：夫乾，天下之至健也，德行恒易以知险。 夫坤，天下之至顺也，德行恒简以知阻。 《上经》常道、常名、太极、虚明，先天之道也。 《下经》上德、不德、乾坤、德行，后天之道也。 亦犹《大易》者，有上下二经。 河上公其不凡乎？ 天地不自有德，是以有德，故为上德。 万物不失天地之德，是以无德，故为下德。 上德无为而四时行焉，无可以为，故曰无为。 下德为之而万物成焉，有可以为，故曰有为。 是以天地万物为上下之德。 人亦物也，物之最灵最贵者，人也，故配天地而为三才，以主万物生成之德。 人之最灵最贵者，圣人也，故主万世治乱之迹，是以上仁为之而无以为。 天地大德，上下应之，何必有为？ 恭己南面而已足矣。 尧舜之世也，上义为之而有以为。 汤武革命，顺乎天而应乎人，商周之世也，上有尧舜之仁应之，上礼为之而莫之应。 周衰礼废，五霸尚争，以力假仁，借名要利，欲以商周之义应之，不其难乎？ 岂止无义，至有攘臂扼吭而相夺者矣。 王狩于河阳，岂上礼之为乎？ 故失道而后德，失德而后仁，失仁而后义，失义而复礼。 至于上礼，忠信之薄而乱之首也。 故前于识者多智，而为道之华愚之始也。 是以大丈夫处其厚不处其薄，居其实不居其华，故去彼之华，取此之实。 德曰：良贾深藏若虚，君子盛德，容貌若愚。 既得先天之道，以成君子之德，被褐怀玉，不自有德，是谓上德。 下德之者，守德不失，方之自然，是谓无德。 上德无为而无可以为，先天无为之道也。 下德为之而有可以为，后天日用之道也。 上仁为之而无以为，取先天一气而为主也。 上义为之而有以为，行周天火候而为宾也。 上礼为之而莫之应，则攘臂而仍之，不知常，妄作凶者也。 故失天而后地，失地而后人，失人而后物，失物而后妄。 夫礼者，妄也，忠信之薄而乱之首也。 前乎识者道之华，先乎知者愚之始，是以大丈夫处其道之厚，不处其华之薄，居其德之实，不居其华之愚也，故曰去彼取此。 昔之得一章第三十九 昔之得一者，天得一以清，地得一以宁，神得一以灵，谷得一以盈，万物得一以生，侯王得一以为天下贞。 其致之一也，天无以清将恐裂，地无以宁将恐发，神无以灵将恐歇，谷无以盈将恐竭，万物无以生将恐灭，侯王无以为贞而贵高将恐蹙。

**Chapter Thirty-Eight: *The Virtue/Power of the Highest Virtue/Power Does Not Virtue/Power***

The highest virtue/power does not virtue/power—
Thus it has virtue/power.
The lowly virtue/power does not lose virtue/power—
Thus it has no virtue/power.

The highest virtue/power acts without action yet nothing is left undone—
The lowly virtue/power acts with action yet nothing is fully accomplished.
The highest benevolence acts yet nothing is left undone—
Virtue/power responds to it.
The highest righteousness acts yet something is left undone—
Benevolence responds to it.
The highest propriety acts yet righteousness does not respond—
Then it rolls up its sleeves and seizes by the throat.

Thus, when the Dao/Way is lost, virtue/power arises;
When virtue/power is lost, benevolence arises;
When benevolence is lost, righteousness arises;
When righteousness is lost, propriety arises.

For propriety is but the thinnest layer of loyalty and trust—
And the beginning of chaos.

Preceding knowledge is the superficial bloom of the Dao/Way—
And the start of folly.

Thus, the true man of virtue dwells in its depth, not its shallowness,
Resides in its substance, not its superficiality—
Hence he discards that and takes this.

The *Classic* states:
The highest virtue/power does not fear losing virtue/power—
Thus it has virtue/power.
The lowly virtue/power fears losing virtue/power—
Thus it has no virtue/power.
The highest virtue/power acts without action yet nothing is left undone—
The lowly virtue/power acts with action yet nothing is fully accomplished.
The highest benevolence acts yet nothing is left undone—
Virtue/power responds to it.
The highest righteousness acts yet something is left undone—
Benevolence responds to it.
The highest propriety acts yet righteousness does not respond—
How much less does it respond?
Then it rolls up its sleeves and seizes by the throat.

Thus, when the Dao/Way is lost, virtue/power arises;
When virtue/power is lost, benevolence arises;
When benevolence is lost, righteousness arises;
When righteousness is lost, propriety arises.
When propriety is lost, it returns to chaos.

For propriety is but the thinnest layer of loyalty and trust—
And the beginning of chaos.
Preceding knowledge and prior awareness are the superficial bloom of the Dao/Way—
And the start of folly.
Thus, the true man of virtue dwells in the Dao/Way’s depth, not its superficial bloom,
Resides in virtue’s substance, not its superficial folly—
Hence he discards that and takes this.

The Dao/Way says:
The *Qian* (乾)—
The most robust of all under Heaven—
Its virtue/power and conduct are ever simple, yet it knows danger.
The *Kun* (坤)—
The most yielding of all under Heaven—
Its virtue/power and conduct are ever unadorned, yet it knows obstruction.

The *Upper Classic* (上经) speaks of the constant Dao/Way,
The constant name, the *Tai Ji* (太极),
And *Xu Ming* (虚明)—
These are the Dao/Way of the Pre-Heaven.
The *Lower Classic* (下经) speaks of the highest virtue/power,
Not virtue/powering, *Qian* and *Kun*,
And virtue/power’s conduct—
These are the Dao/Way of the Post-Heaven.

It is like the *Great Changes* (大易)—
Which also has an Upper and a Lower Classic.

The *Yellow River Master* (河上公) was not ordinary indeed?
Heaven and Earth do not possess virtue/power of their own—
Thus they possess virtue/power.
All things do not lose Heaven and Earth’s virtue/power—
Thus they lack virtue/power.

The highest virtue/power acts without action yet the four seasons proceed—
Without anything to be done, hence it is called *wu wei* (无为).
The lowly virtue/power acts with action yet all things are accomplished—
With something to be done, hence it is called *you wei* (有为).
Thus, Heaven, Earth, and all things are the virtue/power of the highest and lowly.

Man is but one of all things—
The most refined and precious of all things—
Thus he is paired with Heaven and Earth as the *Three Talents* (三才),
To oversee all things’ virtue/power of generation and growth.

The most refined and precious of men—
The sage—
Thus he governs the traces of order and chaos across ten thousand ages—
Hence, the highest benevolence acts yet nothing is left undone.

Heaven and Earth’s great virtue/power—
The highest and lowly respond to it—
Why must there be action?
To be reverent and occupy the southern seat is sufficient.

The age of Yao and Shun—
The highest righteousness acts yet something is left undone—
The sage takes the *One Qi* (一气) of the Pre-Heaven as his master.
The age of Tang and Wu—
Revolution in accordance with Heaven and response to humanity—
The age of Shang and Zhou—
The highest has the benevolence of Yao and Shun to respond to it.
The highest propriety acts yet righteousness does not respond—
How much less does it respond?
Then it rolls up its sleeves and seizes by the throat.

Thus, when the Dao/Way is lost, virtue/power arises;
When virtue/power is lost, benevolence arises;
When benevolence is lost, righteousness arises;
When righteousness is lost, propriety arises.
When propriety is lost, it returns to chaos.

For propriety is but the thinnest layer of loyalty and trust—
And the beginning of chaos.
Preceding knowledge is the superficial bloom of the Dao/Way—
And the start of folly.
Thus, the true man of virtue dwells in the Dao/Way’s depth, not its superficial bloom,
Resides in virtue’s substance, not its superficial folly—
Hence he discards that and takes this.

The *Classic* states:
A fine merchant hides his wares as if he had none—
A man of great virtue/power, though his virtue/power is vast,
His bearing seems like that of a fool.
Having attained the Dao/Way of the Pre-Heaven,
He fulfills the virtue/power of the true man—
Clad in coarse hemp yet holding jade within—
He does not possess virtue/power of his own—
This is called the highest virtue/power.

The lowly virtue/power holds to virtue/power without losing it—
Comparing it to nature—
This is called lacking virtue/power.
The highest virtue/power acts without action yet nothing is left undone—
The Dao/Way of the Pre-Heaven’s *wu wei*.
The lowly virtue/power acts with action yet something is left undone—
The Dao/Way of the Post-Heaven’s daily practice.

The highest benevolence acts yet nothing is left undone—
It takes the *One Qi* of the Pre-Heaven as its master.
The highest righteousness acts yet something is left undone—
It follows the *Fire Candidate* of the *Zhou Tian* (周天) as its guest.
The highest propriety acts yet none respond—
Then it rolls up its sleeves and seizes by the throat—
The ignorant do not know constancy,
And recklessly act as tyrants.

Thus, when Heaven is lost, Earth arises;
When Earth is lost, humanity arises;
When humanity is lost, things arise;
When things are lost, chaos arises.

For propriety is but chaos—
The thinnest layer of loyalty and trust,
And the beginning of chaos.
Preceding knowledge is the superficial bloom of the Dao/Way—
And the start of folly.
Thus, the true man of virtue dwells in the Dao/Way’s depth, not its superficial bloom,
Resides in virtue’s substance, not its superficial folly—
Hence he discards that and takes this.

**Chapter Thirty-Nine: *The Chapter of the Ancient Obtaining of the One***

Those who anciently obtained the One—
Heaven obtained the One and became clear,
Earth obtained the One and became settled,
The *shen* (神) obtained the One and became refined,
The *gu* (谷) obtained the One and became full,
All things obtained the One and were born,
And the feudal lords obtained the One to be the steadfast foundation of all under Heaven.

Their attainment of the One was the same—
Heaven, without the One’s clarity, would fear collapse,
Earth, without the One’s settledness, would fear eruption,
The *shen* (神), without the One’s refinement, would fear exhaustion,
The *gu* (谷), without the One’s fullness, would fear depletion,
All things, without the One’s birth, would fear annihilation,
And the feudal lords, without the One’s steadfast foundation, would fear decline—
Though they were high and noble.

chunks.original_text: 故致数车之用，则无车矣。 是以圣人不欲琭琭落落如玉石之为定体也，故大德不官，大道不器。 道曰：一者，太极一圈也。 是故《易》有太极，是生两仪，两仪生四象，四象生八卦，八卦定吉凶，吉凶生大业。 天、地、神、谷、万物、侯王，其政一也，天无一则必裂，地无一则必发，神无一则必歇，谷无一则必竭，万物无一以生必灭，侯王无一为贞而贵高必蹶。 故贵以贱为本，高以下为基。 是以侯王自称曰孤寡不谷，此其以贱为本邪？ 非与？ 故致车而数其体者，是无车也。 琭琭如玉，落落如石，不欲如此者，形体而言也。 是以圣人贵其用，不贵其体，居其实，不居其华。 德曰：一者，无思无为，神妙致一者也。 故分於道谓之命，形於一谓之性，变於阴阳象形而发谓之生，化穷数尽谓之死。 命者，先天一气也，无物无之。 人有六阳会于一首，故乾为首，天得一以清也。 人有五脏共於一腹，故坤为腹，地得一以宁也。 心为神主，万法皆生，神得一以灵也。 谷神不死，是谓玄牝，谷得一以盈也。 金砂入五内，雾散若风雨，熏蒸达四肢，颜色悦泽好，万物得一以生也。 然后功成名遂，与天地合其德，与日月合其明，与四时合其序，与鬼神合其吉凶，侯王得一以为天下贞也。 故天无以裂而长清，地无以发而长宁，神无以歇而长灵，谷无以竭而长盈，万物无以灭而长生，侯王无以蹶而长贞，其致之一也。 始以至贱之物为本而贵称圣人，始以至下之物为基而高同上天，是以侯王自称孤寡不谷，此其以贱为本邪？ 非与？ 故致车而数其体者，是无车也。 致道数其体者，是无道也。 是以圣人不欲琭琭如玉，落落如石，藏诸用也。 反者道之动章第四十 反者道之动，弱者道之用。 天下之物生於有，有生於无。 经曰：反复道之动也，柔弱道之用也。 天下之物，无生於有，有生於无，原始反终矣。 道曰：复，亨，刚反。 动而以顺行，是以出入无疾，朋来无咎。 反复其道，七日来复。 天行也，复，其见天地之心乎？ 一阳来复，日合天统，天主动，反者道之动也。 临刚浸而长说，而顺刚中而应，大亨以正，天之道也。 至于八月有凶，消不久也。 二阳至临，月合地统，地主静，弱者道之用也。 泰小往大来吉亨，则是天地交而万物通也，上下交而其志同也。 内阳而外阴，内健而外顺，内君子而外小人，君子道长，小人道消也。 三阳交泰，物合人统，人主生，天下之物生於有也。 至于十月坤以藏之，有生于无而又原始反终矣。 德曰：剥之一阳在上，复之一阳在下，夬之一阴在上，姤之一阴在下，乾坤往来，阖辟之门也。 坎为月水而反为中男，离为日火而反为中女。 紫阳有云：日居离位反为女，坎配蟾宫即是男，不会个中类倒意，休将管见事高谈。 又云：若将日用颠倒求，大地尘沙尽成宝。 故曰反者道之动。 毕月为乌，房日为兔，离坎互为其基也。 上善若水，水利万物而不争，故曰弱者道之用。 天下之物皆自无中生有，故曰有生于无； 有中生无，故曰无生于有。 有无之相生，难易之相成，而既济万物也。 上士闻道章第四十一 上士闻道，勤而行之； 中士闻道，若存若亡； 下士闻道，大笑之，不笑不足以为道。 建言有之；

The **Dao** is singular in its essence—
Thus, the *Great Ultimate* is one circle of the Dao.

Therefore, the *Yì* (易) speaks of the *Great Ultimate* (太极),
Which gives birth to the *Two Principles* (兩儀),
The *Two Principles* generate the *Four Symbols* (四象),
The *Four Symbols* produce the *Eight Trigrams* (八卦),
The *Eight Trigrams* determine auspicious and inauspicious,
And auspicious and inauspicious give rise to great undertakings.

Heaven, Earth, the *shen* (神), the *gǔ* (谷), all things, and the feudal lords—
Their governance is one.
Heaven, without the One, would surely crack,
Earth, without the One, would surely erupt,
The *shen*, without the One, would surely falter,
The *gǔ*, without the One, would surely run dry,
All things, without the One to sustain their birth, would surely perish,
And the feudal lords, without the One to uphold their virtue and nobility, would surely decline.

Thus, the noble relies on the lowly as its root,
And the high relies on the lowly as its foundation.
This is why the feudal lords designate themselves as *"gū-guǎ-bùgǔ"* (孤寡不谷),
Taking the lowly as root—
Is this not so?
Is it not so?

Therefore, to focus on the use of many carriages,
Yet count their forms—
This is to have no carriages at all.

The polished brilliance of jade,
The rough solidity of stone—
The sage does not desire such fixed forms,
For the body is but a spoken term.

Thus, the sage values its use,
Not its form,
Resides in its substance,
Not its surface.

**Virtue** says: The One—
No thought, no action,
The divine and mysterious attainment of the One.

Therefore, the division from the Dao is called *ming* (命),
The manifestation of the One is called *xìng* (性),
The transformation through yin and yang, symbolized and expressed, is called *shēng* (生),
The exhaustion of change and the completion of number is called *sǐ* (死).

*Ming* is the primordial *qi* of Heaven,
Without which nothing exists.

Humans have six yang converging at one head—
Thus, *Kàn* (乾) is the head,
And Heaven attains the One with clarity.

Humans have five viscera gathered in one abdomen—
Thus, *Kūn* (坤) is the abdomen,
And Earth attains the One with settledness.

The heart is the sovereign of the *shen*—
All dharmas arise from it,
And the *shen* attains the One with refinement.

The *gǔ*’s *shen* does not die—
This is called the *Mysterious Mother* (玄牝),
And the *gǔ* attains the One with fullness.

Gold and sand enter the five viscera,
Dispersing like mist, like wind and rain,
Perfuming and nourishing to the four limbs,
Enhancing complexion and luster—
All things attain the One with birth.

Then, when achievements are complete and names are fulfilled,
The feudal lord aligns with Heaven and Earth in **virtue**,
With the sun and moon in luminosity,
With the four seasons in order,
And with the spirits and *shen* in auspicious and inauspicious—
This is how the feudal lord attains the One as the steadfast foundation of all under Heaven.

Thus, Heaven, without fear of cracking, endures clarity,
Earth, without fear of eruption, endures settledness,
The *shen*, without fear of exhaustion, endures refinement,
The *gǔ*, without fear of depletion, endures fullness,
All things, without fear of annihilation, endure birth,
And the feudal lords, without fear of decline, endure virtue—
Their attainment of the One is the same.

At first, the most humble things are taken as root,
And the sage is called noble.
At first, the most base things are taken as foundation,
And the high is aligned with Heaven.
Thus, the feudal lords designate themselves as *"gū-guǎ-bùgǔ"*—
Is this not their way of taking the lowly as root?
Is it not so?
Is it not so?

Therefore, to focus on carriages yet count their forms—
This is to have no carriages at all.
To focus on the Dao yet count its forms—
This is to have no Dao at all.

Thus, the sage does not desire
The polished brilliance of jade,
The rough solidity of stone—
But to conceal all uses.

The chapter of **Return** (反), the fourth movement of the Dao:
**Return** is the Dao’s dynamic motion,
**Weakness** is the Dao’s subtle use.

All things under Heaven are born from *yǒu* (有),
And *yǒu* arises from *wú* (無).

The Classic says:
**Return** and **Repetition** (復) are the Dao’s motion,
**Gentleness** and **Weakness** (柔弱) are the Dao’s use.

All things under Heaven,
From *wú* arise in *yǒu*,
And from *yǒu* return to *wú*—
The origin and the end, returning in cycles.

The Dao says:
**Repetition** (復), **Completion** (亨), **Firmness** (剛) returns.
Motion with harmony brings forth,
Thus, entering and exiting without haste,
Friends arriving without blame.

To return and repeat the Dao,
In seven days, it returns again.
The motion of Heaven—
Does it not reveal the heart of Heaven and Earth?

When the One Yang returns,
The sun aligns with Heaven’s order,
Heaven’s motion is primary—
**Return** is the Dao’s dynamic motion.

It faces firmness yet remains gentle,
And in the midst of firmness, it responds.
Great **Completion** with rectitude—
This is the Dao of Heaven.

Until the eighth month, when there is inauspiciousness,
And the decline is not long.

When the Two Yangs reach **Facing** (臨),
The moon aligns with Earth’s order,
Earth’s nature is still—
**Weakness** is the Dao’s subtle use.

**Small Completion** (泰) goes from small to great,
And **Completion** (亨) brings auspiciousness—
This is when Heaven and Earth interact,
And all things are in harmony.
Above and below interact,
And their intentions are unified.

Within, the yang; without, the yin,
Within, vigor; without, compliance,
Within, the *junzi* (君子); without, the *xiǎorén* (小人)—
The *junzi*’s Dao endures,
The *xiǎorén*’s Dao declines.

When the Three Yangs unite in **Small Completion**,
Things align with human order,
The ruler is born—
All things under Heaven are born from *yǒu*.

Until the tenth month, when *Kūn* (坤) conceals it,
And from *yǒu* arises *wú*—
Returning to the origin and the end.

**Virtue** says:
**Shedding** (剥) is when One Yang is above,
**Return** is when One Yang is below,
**Decisive** (夬) is when One Yin is above,
**Meeting** (姤) is when One Yin is below—
*Kàn* and *Kūn* come and go,
The gate of **Closure** and **Opening** (阖辟).

*Kǎn* (坎) is the moon’s water,
And **Return** is the **Middle Male** (中男).
*Lí* (離) is the sun’s fire,
And **Return** is the **Middle Female** (中女).

The *Zǐyáng* (紫陽) says:
The sun dwells in the *Lí* position,
Yet **Return** makes it female;
*Kǎn* is paired with the *Chán* (蟾) palace,
And thus it is male—
If one does not grasp this inverted meaning,
Do not presume to speak of the Dao’s profound truths.

Again it says:
If one seeks to reverse the use of the sun,
The very dust of the earth becomes treasure.

Thus, it is said: **Return** is the Dao’s dynamic motion.

*Bì* (畢) becomes the crow,
*Fáng* (房) becomes the rabbit—
*Lí* and *Kǎn* mutually serve as their foundation.

The **Supreme Virtue** is like water,
Water benefits all things yet does not contend—
Thus, it is said: **Weakness** is the Dao’s subtle use.

All things under Heaven arise from *wú* within *yǒu*,
Thus, it is said: *yǒu* arises from *wú*;
And from *yǒu* arises *wú*—
Thus, it is said: *wú* arises from *yǒu*.
The interplay of *yǒu* and *wú*,
The interplay of difficulty and ease—
And thus all things are **Completed** (既濟).

The chapter of the **Noble Ones Hearing the Dao** (上士聞道):
The **Noble One** hears the Dao,
And diligently practices it;
The **Middle One** hears the Dao,
And holds it with uncertain resolve;
The **Lowly One** hears the Dao,
And laughs at it—
If they do not laugh, it is not the Dao.

There are words to establish this.

chunks.original_text: 明道若昧，进道若退，夷道若类，上德若谷，大白若辱，广德若不足，建德若偷，质真若渝，大方无隅，大器晚成，大音希声，大象无形，道隐无名。 夫惟道，善贷自成。 经曰：上士闻道，动而行之； 中士闻道，若存若亡； 下士闻道，大笑之，不笑不足以为道。 建者至也，故至言有之：明道若昧，进道若退，坦夷同类，上德若谷，大白若辱，广德若不足，至德若薄，质真若变，大方圆而无隅，大器重而晚成，大音和而希声，大象混而无形，大道隐而无名。 夫惟道者，善为推贷而自成。 道曰：上士，善人也。 中士，君子也。 下士，世人也。 大道始则谤世人也，中则疑君子也，终则信善人也。 以其人之资禀品第不同，故有中人上下之分矣。 然谤则何害於疑？ 疑则何害於信？ 信则自信，疑则自疑，谤则自谤，其如大道，何夫勤而行之？ 上知信而不疑者也。 若存若亡，中人可以上下者也。 大笑之，下愚谤而不移者也。 故言不笑不足以为道，此真口诀也。 故至言有之：明道若昧，天造草昧也。 进道若退，震巽消长也。 夷道若类，方以类聚也。 上德若谷，习坎不盈也。 大白若辱，用晦而明也。 广德若不足，地道变盈而流谦也。 建德若偷，天道亏盈而益谦也。 质真若渝，天道无常也。 大方无隅，天包乎地也。 大器晚成，震兑归妹，天地之大义也。 大音希声，雷风水火不相悖而相薄，不相射而相逮也。 大象无形，日月星辰在天而无真形也。 道隐无名，恍惚窈冥，在物而无定名也。 惟此道者，能与天地人物善相推贷，而自成一天地矣，故曰善贷自成。 德曰：古仙有云：人不至九世不得闻道。 上士，九世人也，故闻道勤而行之。 圣人言：中人以上可以语上也。 中士，世人也，故闻道若存若亡。 圣人言：可以上，可以下。 下士，一二世人也，故闻道大笑之。 圣人言：中人以下，不可以语上也。 不笑不足以为道，此语直述其事。 夫道者，天地阴阳至真之气也。 至於蠢动含灵，皆有是性，而况於人乎？ 天地至真之气也，天地絪缊，万物化醇，男女媾精，万物化生。 纯阳有云：回思父母生身处，拍手教人笑一场，正谓此尔。 故言天下之至赜，而不可恶也。 然阴阳二气感应之际，顺则成人，逆为丹用，故曰易逆数也。 顺则成人，十月胎圆养就兄，逆为丹用，十月胎圆入圣机，下士闻此大笑之也。 是不知大笑之者，先笑父母，后笑自身，复遗笑於子孙矣，而又何笑乎？ 玄牝之门，是谓天地根，故曰不笑不足以为道。 故建言有之：明道若昧，藏诸用也。 夷道若类，显诸仁也。 进道若退，柔胜刚也。 上德若谷，弱胜强也。 大白若辱，知荣守辱也。 广德若不足，抱元守一也。 建德若偷，大成若缺，其用不敝也。 质真若渝，大盈若冲，其用不穷也。 大方无隅，有物混成也。 大器晚成，后得主利也。 大音希声，龙吟虎啸也。 大象无形，与道合真也。 道隐无名，神妙至一也。 夫惟道，善贷自成。 分阴分阳，迭用柔刚，故易六位而成章，时乘六龙以御天。 乾道变化，各正性命也。 大哉言乎。 道生一章第四十二 道生一，一生二，二生三，三生万物。 万物负阴而抱阳，冲气以为和。 人之所恶，唯孤寡不谷，而王公以为称。 故物或损之而益，益之而损。
